tn.ref: In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth
tn.text: "This is about how God made  the heavens and the earth in the beginning." This statement summarizes the rest of the chapter.  Some languages translate it as "A very long time ago God created the heavens and the earth." Translate it in a way that shows this actually happened and is not just a folk story.
This refers to the start of the world and everything in it.
"the sky, the ground, and everything in them"
This refers here to the sky.
God had not yet put the world in order.
"the water" or "the deep water" (UDB) or "the vast water"
"the water" or "the surface of the water"
This is a command. By commanding that light should exist, God made it exist. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_imperative]])

tn.ref: God saw the light, that it was good
tn.text: "God considered the light and was pleased with it." "Good" here means "pleasing" or "suitable."

tn.ref: divided the light from the darkness
tn.text: "separated the light and the darkness" or "made it light at one time and dark at another." This refers to God creating the daytime and the night time.

tn.ref: This was evening and morning, the first day
tn.text: God did these things on the first day that the universe existed.
This refers to the whole day. The writer speaks of the whole day as if it were these two parts. In the Jewish culture, a day begins when the sun sets. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

tn.ref: Let there be an expanse ... let it divide
tn.text: These are commands. By commanding that the expanse should exist and that it divide the waters, God made it exist and divide the waters. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_imperative]])
"large empty space." The Jewish people thought of this space as being shaped like the inside of dome or the inside of a bowl that is turned upside down.
"in the water"

tn.ref: God made the expanse and divided the waters
tn.text: "In this way God made the expanse and divided the waters." When God spoke, it happened. This sentence explains what God did when he spoke.
"It happened like that" or "That is what happened." What God commanded happened just as he said it should. This phrase appears throughout the chapter and has the same meaning wherever it appears.

This refers to the whole day. The writer speaks of the whole day as if it were these two parts. In the Jewish culture, a day begins when the sun sets. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:03|1:5]]. (See: Merism)
This refers to the second day that the universe existed. See how you translated "the first day" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:03|1:5]] and decide if you should translate this the same way.

This can be translated with an active verb.  This is a command. By commanding that the waters gather together, God made them gather together. AT: "Let the waters ... gather" or "Let the waters ... come together" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_imperative]])

The water had covered the land. Now the water would move aside and some of the land would be uncovered. This is a command. By commanding that dry land should appear, God made it appear. AT: "let dry land become visible" or "let the dry land become clear" or "let the land be uncovered" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_imperative]])
This refers to land that is not covered with water. It does not refer to land that is too dry for farming.

"It happened like that" or "That is what happened." What God commanded happened just as he said it should. This phrase appears throughout the chapter and has the same meaning wherever it appears. Translate this as it is in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:06|1:7]].
"land" or "ground"

tn.ref: He saw that it was good
tn.text: Here "it" refers to the land and the sea. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:03|1:4]].

This is a command. By commanding that vegetation should sprout on the earth, God made it sprout. AT: "Let vegetation sprout up on the earth" or "Let vegetation grow on the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_imperative]])

tn.ref: vegetation: plants yielding seed and fruit trees bearing fruit
tn.text: "vegetation, each plant that bears seed and each tree that bears fruit" or "vegetation. Let them be plants that produce seeds and fruit trees that produce fruit." Vegetation" is used here as a general term that includes all plants and trees.
These are kinds of vegetation that have soft stems, rather than woody stems.

tn.ref: fruit trees bearing fruit whose seed is in the fruit
tn.text: "trees that bear fruit with seeds in them"

tn.ref: each according to its own kind
tn.text: The seeds would produce plants and trees that would be like the ones they came from. In this way, the plants and trees would "reproduce themselves" (UDB).

"It happened like that" or "That is what happened." What God commanded happened just as he said it should. This phrase appears throughout the chapter and has the same meaning wherever it appears. Translate this as it is in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:06|1:7]].

tn.ref: God saw that it was good
tn.text: Here "it" refers to the vegetation, plants, and trees. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:09|1:10]].

This refers to the whole day. The writer speaks of the whole day as if it were these two parts. In the Jewish culture, a day begins when the sun sets. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:03|1:5]]. (See: Merism)
This refers to the third day that the universe existed. See how you translated "the first day" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:03|1:5]] and decide if you should translate this the same way.

tn.ref: Let there be lights in the sky
tn.text: This is a command. By commanding that lights should exist, God made them exist. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_imperative]])
"things that shine in the sky" or "things that give light in the sky." This refers to the sun, moon, and stars.
"in the expanse of the sky" or "in the large space of the sky"

tn.ref: to divide the day from the night
tn.text: "to separate the day from the night." This means "to help us tell the difference between day and night." The sun means it is daytime, and the moon and stars mean it is nighttime.
This is a command. By commanding that they should serve as signs, God made them serve as signs. AT: "Let them serve as signs" or "let them show" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_imperative]])
Here this means something that reveals or points to something.
"Seasons" refers to times that are set aside for festivals and other things that people do.

tn.ref: for seasons, for days and years
tn.text: The sun, moon, and stars show the passing of time. This enables us to know when it is time for events that happen each week, month, or year.

tn.ref: Let them be lights in the sky to give light upon the earth
tn.text: This is a command. By commanding that they should light the earth, God made them light the earth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_imperative]])

tn.ref: to give light upon the earth
tn.text: "to shine light on the earth" or "to brighten the earth." The earth does not self-shine but it is lit and so reflects light.

"It happened like that" or "That is what happened." What God commanded happened just as he said it should. This phrase appears throughout the chapter and has the same meaning.  See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:06|1:7]].

tn.ref: God made the two great lights
tn.text: "In this way God made the two great lights." This sentence explains what God did when he spoke.
"the two large lights" or "the two bright lights." The two great lights are the sun and the moon.
"to direct the daytime as a ruler directs a group of people" or "to mark the times of the day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
This refers only to the daylight hours.
"the smaller light" or "the dimmer light"
"in the heavens" or "in the open space of the sky"

tn.ref: to divide the light from the darkness
tn.text: "to separate the light from the darkness" or "to make it light at one time and dark at another." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:03|1:4]].

tn.ref: God saw that it was good
tn.text: Here "it" refers to the sun, moon, and stars. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:03|1:4]].

This refers to the whole day. The writer speaks of the whole day as if it were these two parts. In the Jewish culture, a day begins when the sun sets. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:03|1:5]]. (See: Merism)
This refers to the fourth day that the universe existed. See how you translated "the first day" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:03|1:5]] and decide if you should translate this the same way.

tn.ref: Let the waters be filled with great numbers of living creatures
tn.text: This is a command. By commanding that living creatures should fill the waters, God made them exist. Some languages may have one word that refers to all kinds of fish and sea animals. AT: "Let the waters be full of many living things" or "Let many animals that swim live in the oceans" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_imperative]])
This is a command. By commanding that birds should fly, God made them fly. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_imperative]])
"animals that fly" or "flying things"
"the open space of the sky" or "the sky"
"In this way God created"
"large animals that live in the sea"
Living things of the same "kind" are like the ones they came from. See how you translated "kind" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:11|1:11,12]].
"every flying thing that has wings." If the word for birds is used, it may be more natural in some languages to simply say "every bird," since all birds have wings.

tn.ref: God saw that it was good
tn.text: Here "it" refers to the birds and the fish. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:03|1:4]].
"blessed the animals that he had made"

This is God's blessing. He told the sea animals to produce more sea animals like themselves, so that there would be many of them in the seas. The word "multiply" explains how they are to be "fruitful." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"increase greatly in number" or "become many"
This is a command. By commanding that birds should multiply, God made birds multiply. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_imperative]])
"animals that fly" or "flying things." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:20|1:20]].

This refers to the whole day. The writer speaks of the whole day as if it were these two parts. In the Jewish culture, a day begins when the sun sets. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:03|1:5]]. (See: Merism)
This refers to the fifth day that the universe existed. See how you translated "the first day" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:03|1:5]] and decide if you should translate this the same way.

tn.ref: Let the earth produce living creatures
tn.text: "Let the earth produce living things" or "Let many living animals live on the earth." This is a command. By commanding that the earth should produce living creatures, God made the earth produce living creatures. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_imperative]])

tn.ref: each according to its own kind
tn.text: "so that each kind of animal will produce more of its own kind"

tn.ref: livestock, creeping things, and beasts of the earth
tn.text: This shows that God created all kinds of animals. If your language has another way of grouping all the animals, you can use that, or you can use these groups.
"animals that people look after"
"small animals"
"wild animals" or "dangerous animals"

"It happened like that" or "That is what happened." What God commanded happened just as he said it should. This phrase appears throughout the chapter and has the same meaning.  See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:06|1:7]].
"In this way God made the beasts"

tn.ref: He saw that it was good
tn.text: Here "it" refers to the living creatures on the earth. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:03|1:4]].

The word "us" here refers to God. God was saying what he intended to do. The pronoun "us" is plural. Possible reasons for the plural use are 1) the plural form suggests that God is discussing something with the angels that make up his heavenly court or 2) the plural form foreshadows the later New Testament implications that God exists in the form of the Holy Trinity. Some translate it as "Let me make" or "I will make." If you do this, consider adding a footnote to say that the word is plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pronouns]])
"human beings" or "people." This word here does not mean males only.

tn.ref: in our image, after our likeness
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that God made mankind to be like him. This verse does not tell in what ways God made people to be like himself. God does not have a body, so it does not mean that people would look like God. AT: "to truly be like us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pronouns]])
"rule over" or "have authority over"

tn.ref: God created man ... he created him
tn.text: These two sentences mean the same thing and emphasize that God created people in his own image. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
The way that God created man was different from the way he created everything else. Do not specify that he created man by simply speaking, as in the preceding verses.
The word "them" refers to the man and woman God had created.

God told the man and the woman to produce more people like themselves so that there would be many of them. The word "multiply" explains how they are to be "fruitful." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:22|1:22]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Fill the earth with people.
God continues speaking.
"all the birds that fly in the sky"

tn.ref: that has the breath of life
tn.text: "that breathes" (UDB). This phrase emphasizes that these animals had a different kind of life than the plants. Plants do not breathe, and were to be used as food for the animals. Here "life" means physical life.

"It happened like that" or "That is what happened." What God commanded happened just as he said it should. This phrase appears throughout the chapter and has the same meaning.  See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:06|1:7]].
"Indeed." The word "behold" here adds emphasis to what follows.
Now when God looked at everything he had made, it was "very good. "See how you translated "it was good" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:09|1:10]].

This refers to the whole day. The writer speaks of the whole day as if it were these two parts. In the Jewish culture, a day begins when the sun sets. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:03|1:5]]. (See: Merism)
This refers to the sixth day that the universe existed. See how you translated "the first day" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:03|1:5]] and decide if you should translate this the same way.
"the sky" or "the skies"

tn.ref: and all the living things that filled them
tn.text: "and all the many living things that are in them" or "and all the crowds of living things in them"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God had finished creating them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: On the seventh day God came to the end of his work
tn.text: God did not work at all on the seventh day.
This is an idiom. AT: "had finished" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: he rested on the seventh day from all his work
tn.text: "on that day he did not work"
Possible meanings are 1) God caused the seventh day to produce good result or 2) God said that the seventh day was good.
"and set it apart" or "and called it his own"

tn.ref: in it he rested from all his work
tn.text: "on it he did not work"
The rest of Genesis 2 tells about how God created people on the sixth day.

tn.ref: These were the events concerning the heavens and the earth
tn.text: "This is the account of the heavens and the earth" or "This is the story about the heavens and the earth." Possible meanings are 1) it is a summary of the events described in Genesis 1:1-2:3 or 2) it introduces the events described in Genesis 2. If possible, translate this so that people can understood it either way.
"Yahweh God created them." In chapter 1 the writer always speaks of God as "God," but in chapter 2 he always speaks of God as "Yahweh God."

tn.ref: on the day that Yahweh God made
tn.text: "when Yahweh God created." The word "day" refers to the whole time span of the creation, not to just one particular day.
no shrubs growing in the wild that animals might eat
no leafy plants like vegetables or greens that both animals and humans can eat
to do everything he needed to do so that the plants would grow well
Possible meanings are 1) something like dew or morning fog o 2) springs from underground streams.

tn.ref: the whole surface of the ground
tn.text: the entire earth
"molded" or "shaped" or "created"
"a human being ... the human" or "a person ... the person" not specifically a male
"his nose"
"breath that makes things live." Here "life" refers to physical life.
This could have been an orchard of fruit trees or an area with all kinds of trees.
"in the east"
"the tree that gives people life"
Here this means "eternal life" or life that does not end.

tn.ref: the tree of the knowledge of good and evil
tn.text: "the tree that gives people the ability to understand both good and evil" or "the tree that makes people who eat its fruit able to know good things and bad things"
This is a figure of speech that refers to both extremes and everything in between. AT: "everything, including both good and evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

tn.ref: in the midst of the garden
tn.text: "in the middle of the garden." The two trees may not have been in the exact center of the garden.

tn.ref: A river went out of Eden to water the garden
tn.text: The garden was in Eden. The river continued to flow outside of Eden. AT: "A river flowed through Eden to water the garden."
This is the only time this river is referred to in the Bible. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]]).
"the whole land called Havilah." It was somewhere in the Arabian Desert. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]]).
This phrase gives information about Havilah. Some languages would translate it as a separate sentence. AT: "There is gold in Havilah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_distinguish]])

tn.ref: There are also  bdellium and the onyx stone
tn.text: The word "there" is placed first in the sentence for emphasis. AT: "This is also where people can find bdellium and onyx stones"
This resin comes from a tree and smells nice. A resin is sticky stuff that comes out of some trees and can burn. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
"onyx stones." Onyx is a certain kind of beautiful stone. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
This is the only mention of this river in the Bible. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: flows throughout the whole land of Cush
tn.text: The river did not cover the whole land, but wound through various parts of the land.
"the entire land called Cush"

"which flows in the land east of the city of Asshur." The Tigris River flows from north to south. The phrase "which flows east of Asshur" gives information about where the Tigris River is. Some languages would translate it as a separate sentence. AT: "and it flows east of Asshur" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_distinguish]])
"the garden that was in Eden"
"to cultivate it." This means to do everything necessary so that the plants will grow well.
to guard against anything bad happening in it

tn.ref: From every tree in the garden
tn.text: "The fruit of every tree in the garden"
This pronoun is singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: you may freely eat ... you may not eat
tn.text: In some languages it would be natural to first say what is not permitted and to then say what is permitted, as in the UDB.
"may eat without restriction"

tn.ref: the tree of the knowledge of good and evil
tn.text: "the tree that gives people the ability to understand both good and evil" or "the tree that makes people who eat its fruit able to know good things and bad things." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:02:09|2:9]].
"I will not permit you to eat" (UDB) or "you must not eat"

tn.ref: I will make him a helper suitable for him
tn.text: "I will make a helper who is just right for him"

tn.ref: every animal of the field and every bird of the sky
tn.text: The phrases "of the field" and "of the sky" tell where the animals and birds are usually found. AT: "all kinds of animals and birds."
"all the animals that people look after"

tn.ref: there was found no helper suitable for him
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "there was no companion that was right for him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: caused a deep sleep to fall upon the man
tn.text: "caused the man to sleep intensely." A deep sleep is a time of sleeping in which a person is not easily disturbed or wakened.

tn.ref: With the rib ... he made a woman
tn.text: "From the rib ... he formed a woman." The rib was the material God made the woman from.

tn.ref: This time, this one is bone of my bones, and flesh of my flesh
tn.text: "Finally, this one's bones are like my bones, and her flesh is like my flesh." After looking among all the animals for a partner and not finding one, he finally saw someone who was like him and could be his partner. The man was probably expressing his feeling of relief and joy.
This refers to the soft parts of the body like skin and muscle.

tn.ref: She will be called 'woman,' because she was taken out of man
tn.text: The translator may want to write a footnote saying "The Hebrew word for 'woman' sounds like the Hebrew word for 'man.'
What follows is written by the author. The man did not say these things.
"That is why"

tn.ref: a man will leave his father and his mother
tn.text: "a man will stop living in his father and mother's home." This is about men in general. It does not refer to any particular man at any particular time.
This idiom speaks of sexual activity as though the bodies that are together become one body. AT: "their two bodies will become one body" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The word "they" refers to the man and the woman that God had created.
"not wearing clothing"
"they were not ashamed about being naked" (UDB)
The writer is beginning a new part of the story.
"more cunning" (UDB) or "smarter at getting what he wanted by telling lies"

The snake is pretending to be surprised that God has made this rule. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "I am surprised that God said, 'You ... garden.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The word "you" is plural and refers to the man and the woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: We may eat ... God said, 'You may not eat it
tn.text: Eve told the serpent what God had permitted them to do first and then what God had told them not to do. Some languages would say what they were told not to do first and then say what they were allowed to do, as in the UDB.
"We are allowed to eat" or "We have permission to eat"

tn.ref: You may not ... nor may you ... you will die
tn.text: The word "you" is plural and refers to the man and the woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"You must not eat it" or "Do not eat it"
"and you must not touch it" or "and do not touch it"
These words refer to the man and the woman and so are dual or plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

"your eyes will open." This idiom means "you will become aware of things" or "you will understand new things." This meaning can be stated clearly. AT: "It will be as though your eyes were opened" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Here "good and evil" is a figure of speech that refers to both extremes and everything in between. AT: "knowing everything, including both good and evil." See how you translated "knowledge of good and evil" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:02:09|2:9]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

tn.ref: it was a delight to the eyes
tn.text: "the tree was delightful to look at" or "it was nice to look at" or "it was very beautiful" (UDB)

tn.ref: and that the tree was desirable to make one wise
tn.text: "and she wanted the tree's fruit because it could make a person wise" or "and she wanted its fruit because it could make her understand what was right and wrong just as God does"

tn.ref: The eyes of both of them were opened
tn.text: "Then their eyes opened" or "They became aware" or "They understood." See how you translated "your eyes will be opened" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:03:04|3:5]].
"fastened" or "joined"
If people do not know what fig leaves are like, this can be translated as "large leaves from a fig tree" or simply "large leaves."

They did this because they were ashamed. This implicit information can be made explicit if needed as in the UDB. AT: "and clothed themselves with them because they were ashamed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: in the cool of the day
tn.text: "at the time of day when a cool breeze blows"

tn.ref: from the presence of Yahweh God
tn.text: "from Yahweh God's sight" or "so that Yahweh God would not see them" (UDB) or "from Yahweh God"
"Why are you trying to hide from me?" (UDB). God knew where the man was. When the man answered, he did not say where he was but why he was hiding.
In verses 9 and 11, God was speaking to the man. Languages that have a singular form of "you" would use that here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"I heard the sound you were making"
God knew the answer to this question. He asked it in order to force Adam to confess that he had disobeyed God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

Again, God knew this had happened. Translate this question in a form that shows God was accusing Adam of disobedience. The sentence can be translated as a statement. AT: "You must have eaten ... from." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: What is this you have done?
tn.text: God already knew what the woman had done. When he asked this question, he was giving her the opportunity to tell him about it, and he was expressing his disappointment with what she had done. Many languages use rhetorical questions for scolding or rebuking. If possible, use a form that expresses this disappointment. It can also be translated as a statement. AT: "You have done a terrible thing." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

"you alone are cursed." The word "curse" is first in Hebrew in order to emphasize the contrast between God's blessing on the animals and this curse on the serpent. This is a "curse formula," or the way that curses were expressed. By saying this curse, God made it happen.

tn.ref: all the livestock and all the beasts of the field
tn.text: "all domestic animals and all wild animals"

tn.ref: It is on your stomach that you will go
tn.text: "You will move along the ground on your stomach." The words "it is upon your stomach" comes first to emphasize the contrast between the way other animals would move along using their legs and the way the serpent would slither along on its stomach. This is also part of the curse formula.

tn.ref: it is dust that you will eat
tn.text: "you will eat dust." The words "it is dust" comes first to emphasize the contrast between the plants above the ground that other animals would eat and the dirty food on the ground that the serpent would eat. This is part of the curse formula.

tn.ref: hostility between you and the woman
tn.text: This means that the serpent and the woman would become enemies.

"offspring" or "descendant." The word "seed" refers to what a man puts into a woman to cause a baby to grow inside the woman. Like the word "offspring," it can refer to more than one person, as in the word "descendants." Try to find a word that is singular but can refer to more than one person.

The words "he" and "his" refer to the woman's descendant. If "seed" was translated as plural, this can be translated as "they will bruise ... their heel"; in this case, consider inserting footnotes to say that the "they" and "their" are used to translate a singular pronoun. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pronouns]])
"crush" or "strike" or "attack"

tn.ref: I will greatly multiply your pain
tn.text: "I will make your pain increase much" or "I will make your pain to be very severe"
"in giving birth to children" or "when you give birth to children" (UDB)

tn.ref: Your desire will be for your husband
tn.text: "You will have a strong desire for your husband." Possible meanings are 1) "You will want very much to be with your husband" or 2) "You will want to control your husband"
"he will be your master" or "he will control you"
The name Adam is the same as the Hebrew word for "man." Some translations say "Adam" and some say "the man." You may use either form as it refers to the same person.

tn.ref: you have listened to the voice of your wife
tn.text: This is an idiom. AT: "you have obeyed what your wife said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
You can say what it was that they ate. AT: "have eaten the fruit of the tree" or "have eaten some of the fruit of the tree" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: You may not eat from it
tn.text: "You must not eat from it" or "Do not eat its fruit"

The word "curse" comes first in the sentence to emphasize that the ground, which had been "good" ([[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:09|1:10]]), was now under God's curse. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I am cursing the ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"by doing hard work"

The word "it" refers to the ground and is a metonym for the parts of the plants, which grow in the ground, that people eat. AT: "you will eat what grows from it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Possible meanings are 1) "the plants that you take care of in your fields" or 2) "the wild plants that grow in the open fields."

tn.ref: By the sweat of your face
tn.text: "By doing hard work that makes your face sweat"
Here the word "bread" is a synecdoche for food in general. AT: "you will eat food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: until you return to the ground
tn.text: "until you die and your body is put in the ground." In some cultures, they put the bodies of people who have died in a hole in the ground. Man's hard work does not end until the time of his death and burial.

tn.ref: For dust you are, and to dust you will return
tn.text: "I made you from soil, so your body will become soil again." Translate both occurrences of "dust" with the same word in order to show that man begins and ends in the same condition.
Some translations say "Adam."
"gave his wife the name Eve" or "named his wife Eve" (UDB)
Translators may write a footnote saying "The name Eve sounds like the Hebrew word that means 'living.'"
The word "living" refers to people. AT: "all the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"clothing made out of animal skins"

Possible meanings are 1) God was referring to one human, the man, or 2) God was referring to humans in general, so this would mean the man and his wife. Even if God was speaking about one person, what he said applied to both of them.
"like us." The pronoun "us" is plural. See how you translated "Let us make" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:26|1:26]].

Here "good and evil" is a figure of speech that refers to both extremes and everything in between. See how you translated "knowledge of good and evil" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:02:09|2:9]]. AT: "knowing everything, including both good and evil"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will not allow him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"the tree that gives people life." Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:02:07|2:9]].

tn.ref: the ground from which he had been taken
tn.text: "dirt because he had been taken from dirt." This does not refer to the particular place on the land that the God took man from.

tn.ref: So God drove the man out of the garden
tn.text: "God forced the man to leave the garden." This refers to the event in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:03:22|3:23]], where it says "Yahweh God sent him out of the garden of Eden." God did not send the man out a second time.
This means to what is needed so that plants grow well. Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:02:04|2:5]].

tn.ref: in order to guard the way to the tree of life
tn.text: "in order to stop people from going to the tree of life"
Possible meanings are 1) a sword that had flames coming from it or 2) a fire that was shaped like a sword. Languages that do not have swords could use another weapon such as a spear or arrow.
"the human being" or "Adam" (UDB)
Your language may have a way of saying this politely. Some older versions say "knew." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
The word for "man" typically describes an adult male, rather than a baby or child. If that would cause confusion, it could be translated as "manchild" or "boy" or "baby boy" or "son."

Translators may want to include a footnote that says "The name Cain sounds like the Hebrew word that means 'produce.' Eve named him Cain because she produced him." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

We do not know how much time passed between the births of Cain and Abel. They may have been twins, or Abel may have been born after Eve became pregnant again. If possible, use an expression that does not tell how much time passed.
This means he did everything he needed to do so that the plants would grow well. See how "cultivate" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:02:04|2:5]].
This phrase is used to mark the beginning of a new part of the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using that method here.
Possible meanings are 1) "after some time had passed" or 2) "at the right time"
This refers to the food that came from plants he had tended. AT: "crops" or "harvest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to the fatty parts of the lambs that he had killed, it was the best part of the animal. AT: "some of their fat parts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"looked favorably upon" or "was pleased with"
Some languages have an idiom for anger such as "He burned" or "His anger burned."

This means that the expression on his face showed that he was angry or jealous. Some languages have an idiom that describes what a person's face looks like when he is angry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Why are you angry and why are you scowling?
tn.text: God used these rhetorical questions to tell Cain that he was wrong to be angry and scowl. They may also have been intended to give Cain an opportunity to confess that he was wrong. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: If you ... will you not be accepted?
tn.text: God used this rhetorical question to remind Cain of something Cain should have already known. AT: "You know that if you do what is right, I will accept you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: But if you do not ... you must rule over it
tn.text: God speaks of sin as if it were a person. AT: "But if you do not do what is right, you will desire to sin even more, and then you will do sinful things. You must refuse to obey it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

Here sin is spoken of as a dangerous wild animal that is waiting for the chance to attack Cain. AT: "you will become so angry that you will not be able to stop sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Languages that do not have a noun that means "sin" could translate this as "your desire to sin" or "the bad things you want to do."
Yahweh speaks of Cain's desire to sin as if it were a person over whom Cain should rule. AT: "you must control it so you do not sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Cain spoke to Abel his brother
tn.text: Some languages will need to add the implicit information that Cain spoke to his brother about going to the fields. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Abel was Cain's younger brother. Some languages may need to use the word for "younger brother." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"attacked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
God knew that Cain had killed Abel, but he asked Cain this question so that Cain would have to answer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

Cain used this rhetorical question in order to avoid telling the truth. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "I am not my brother's keeper!" or "Taking care of my brother is not my job!" (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
God uses a rhetorical question to rebuke Cain. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "What you have done is terrible!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Your brother's blood is calling out to me
tn.text: Abel's blood is a metonym for his death, as if it were a person calling out for God to punish Cain. AT: "Your brother's blood is like a person calling out to me to punish the person who killed him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Now cursed are you from the ground
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "I am cursing you so that you will not be able to grow food from the ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: which has opened its mouth to receive your brother's blood
tn.text: God speaks of the earth as if it were a person who could drink Abel's blood. AT: "which is soaked with your brother's blood" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

God speaks of Cain's hand as if it had poured Abel's blood into the ground's "mouth." AT: "that spilled when you killed him" or "from you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This means to do everything necessary to do so that the plants would grow well. See how "cultivate" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:02:04|2:5]].

tn.ref: it will not yield to you its strength
tn.text: The ground is personified as if it were a person who loses strength. AT: "the ground will not produce much food for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
You can join these words together. AT: "A homeless wanderer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hendiadys]])

tn.ref: I will be hidden from your face
tn.text: The term "your face" represents God's presence. AT: "I will not be able to speak to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:04:10|4:12]]

tn.ref: vengeance will be taken on him sevenfold
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will take vengeance on him seven times" or "I will punish that person seven times as severely as I am punishing you" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"would not kill Cain"

tn.ref: went out from the presence of Yahweh
tn.text: Even though Yahweh is everywhere, this idiom speaks of Cain as though he went far away. AT: "went away from where Yahweh spoke to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

"Cain built a city"

tn.ref: He was the father of those who play the harp and pipe

tn.ref: Tubal Cain, the forger of tools of bronze and iron

Here "flesh" represents all physical beings, including humans and animals. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: that has in it the breath of life
tn.text: Here "breath" represents life. AT: "that lives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"make a covenant between you and me"
with Noah

tn.ref: You will come into the ark
tn.text: "You will enter the ark." Some translations say "You will go into the ark."

tn.ref: Of every living creature of all flesh, two of every kind you must bring into the ark
tn.text: "You must bring into the ark two of every kind of living creature"
an animal God created
Translate these words as in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:06:11|6:12]].
"of each different kind"
This refers to small animals that move on the ground (UDB).
This refers to two of every kind of bird and animal.
"so you can keep them alive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
These refer to Noah and are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"food that people and animals eat"

tn.ref: So Noah did this. According to all that God commanded him, so he did
tn.text: These two sentences mean the same thing. The second sentence explains the first and emphasizes that Noah obeyed God. These parallel sentences can be combined into one. AT: "So Noah did everything that God commanded him to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
The events in this chapter take place after Noah built the ark, gathered the food, and put it in the ark.
"Enter ... into the ark ... take." Many translations read "Go ... into the ark ... take."  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])
The word "you" refers to Noah and is singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"your family"
This means that God saw Noah as righteous.
This refers to all the people who were living at that time. AT: "among all the people who are now living"
This was an animal that God allowed his people to eat and to sacrifice.
These were animals that God did not allow people to eat or to sacrifice.
"so that they will have offspring that will live" or "so that, after the flood, animals will continue to live"
This was a full forty days. It was not a total of eighty days. AT: "forty days and nights"
This refers to physical life.
Verses 6-12 repeat for a second time and give more detail about how Noah went into the ark with his family and the animals in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:07:01|7:1-5]]. This is not a new event.
"happened" or "came on the earth"

tn.ref: because of the waters of the flood
tn.text: "because of the flood that would come" or "to escape the flood water"
Verses 6-12 repeat for a second time and give more detail about how Noah went into the ark with his family and the animals in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:07:01|7:1-5]]. This is not a new event.
These were animals that God allowed people to eat and to give to him as sacrifices.
These were animals that God did not allow people to eat or to give to him as sacrifices.
The animals entered the boat in pairs of one male and one female.
This phrase is used here to mark an important event in the story: the start of the flood. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.
"after seven days" or "seven days later"

tn.ref: the waters of the flood came upon the earth
tn.text: The implicit information, "it started to rain" can be made explicit (UDB). AT: "it started to rain and the waters of the flood came upon the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Verses 6-12 repeat for a second time and give more detail about how Noah went into the ark with his family and the animals in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:07:01|7:1-5]]. This is not a new event.

tn.ref: In the six hundredth year of Noah's life
tn.text: "When Noah was 600 years old" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])

tn.ref: the second month, on the seventeenth day of the month
tn.text: Since Moses wrote this book, it is possible he is referring to the second month of the Hebrew calendar. But this is uncertain. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_hebrewmonths]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
This refers to the specific day when the rain began. This phrase emphasizes how all of these major events happened quickly when the time arrived.

tn.ref: the fountains of the great deep burst open
tn.text: "water from under the earth rushed up to the earth's surface"
This refers to the sea that was thought to be under the earth.

tn.ref: the windows of heaven were opened
tn.text: This refers to rain. It describes the sky as a ceiling that keeps the waters above it from falling down to the earth. When the windows, or doors, in the sky were opened, the water came down through them. AT: "the sky opened" or "the doors in the sky opened"
If your language has a word for a great amount of rain, it would be appropriate here.
Verses 13-18 repeat for a third time and give more detail about how Noah went into the ark with his family and the animals in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:07:01|7:1-5]]. This is not a new event.
"On that exact day." This refers to the day that the rain started. Verses 13-16 tell what Noah did immediately before the rain began.

tn.ref: wild animal ... livestock ... creeping thing ... bird
tn.text: These four groups are listed to show that every kind of animal was included. If your language has another way of grouping all the animals, you can use that, or you can use these groups. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:24|1:24]].
This refers to animals that crawl on the ground, like rodents, insects, lizards, and snakes.
"so that each kind of animal will produce more of its own kind." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:24|1:24]].
Verses 13-18 repeat for a third time and give more detail about how Noah went into the ark with his family and the animals in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:07:01|7:1-5]]. This is not a new event.
Here "flesh" represents animals. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: in which was the breath of life
tn.text: Here "breath" represents life. AT: "that lived" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "came" can be translated as "went." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])
Here "flesh" represents animals. AT: "of every kind of animal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The full meaning can be stated explicitly. AT: "after they entered the ark" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Verses 13-18 repeat for a third time and give more detail about how Noah went into the ark with his family and the animals in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:07:01|7:1-5]]. This is not a new event.
This happened during the forty days while the water kept coming. "and the water became very deep"
"and it caused the ark to float"
"causes the ark to rise up high over the ground" or "he ark floated on top of the deep water"

tn.ref: The waters rose greatly on the earth
tn.text: "The water totally overwhelmed the earth"
"six meters." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:06:13|6:15]].
"moved about" or "roamed"

tn.ref: all living beings that moved upon the earth
tn.text: This refers to all the animals that move around on the ground in large groups.

tn.ref: who breathed the breath of life through their noses
tn.text: Here "noses" represent the whole animal or human. AT: "everyone that breathed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The words "breath" and "life" represent the power that causes people and animals to be alive. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to physical death.

tn.ref: So every living thing ... was wiped out
tn.text: If necessary, this can be stated in active form. AT: "So every living thing ... perished" or "So the flood completely destroyed every living thing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God destroyed them all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"so they were no longer on the earth"
"and the people and animals that were with him"
"remained" or "lived" or "remained alive" (UDB)
"The deep water covered all the earth" or "The waters remained at full flood on the earth" (UDB)
"remembered" or "thought about"
This refers to a very large box that would be able to float on water even in a very bad storm. AT: "a large boat" or "a ship" or "a barge." Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:06:13|6:14]].

tn.ref: The fountains of the deep and the windows of heaven were closed
tn.text: "The water stopped coming out of the ground and the rain stopped falling." This can be stated in active form. AT: "God closed the fountains of the deep and the windows of heaven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"water from under the earth." See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:07:11|7:11]].

tn.ref: the windows of heaven were closed
tn.text: This refers to the rain stopping. It describes the sky as a ceiling that keeps the waters above it from falling down to the earth. When the windows, or doors, in the sky were closed, the water stopped coming through them. AT: "the sky closed" or "the doors in the sky closed." See how "the windows of heaven" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:07:11|7:11]].
"landed" or "stopped on solid ground"

tn.ref: in the seventh month, on the seventeenth day of the month ... tenth month
tn.text: Because Moses wrote this book, it is possible he is referring to the seventh month and tenth month of the Hebrew calendar, but this is uncertain. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_hebrewmonths]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])

tn.ref: On the first day of the month
tn.text: "On the first day of the tenth month"
This can be made more explicit: "appeared above the surface of the water." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This phrase is used here to mark the beginning of a new part of the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here. AT: "It happened that"

tn.ref: It came about ... the window of the ark which he had made
tn.text: The phrase "which he had made" tells about the window. Some languages may need to make this phrase a separate sentence: "Noah had made a window in the boat. It came about after forty days that he opened the window" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_distinguish]])
a black bird that eats mainly the flesh of dead animals
This means that the raven kept leaving the boat and returning.

tn.ref: until the water was dried up
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "until the wind dried up the water" or "until the water dried up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"to land" or "to perch." It means to land on something in order to rest from flying.

tn.ref: her foot ... she returned ... and brought her
tn.text: The word "dove" is feminine in the author's language. You could translate these phrases with the pronouns "its ... it ... it" or "his ... he ... him," depending on how your language refers to a dove.
If you use masculine pronouns for the word "dove," you may need to insert Noah's name here to avoid confusion: "Noah sent out a dove," "Noah stretched forth his hand," etc.
"Pay attention" or "This is important"
"a leaf that she had just plucked from an olive tree"
"broken off"
"He again waited for seven days"

tn.ref: She did not return again to him
tn.text: If people would not understand, you could state the reason explicitly: "She did not return again to him because she found a place to land." (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This phrase is used here to mark the beginning of a new part of the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.

tn.ref: in the six hundred and first year
tn.text: "when Noah was 601 years old" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])

tn.ref: the first month, on the first day of the month
tn.text: Since Moses wrote this book it is possible he is referring to the first month of the Hebrew calendar, but this is uncertain. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_hebrewmonths]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])

tn.ref: the waters were dried up from off the earth
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the waters covering the earth dried up" or "the wind dried up the waters covering the earth" (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]]).
This refers to a cover that kept the rain water from going into the ark.
The word "behold" tells us to pay attention to the important information that comes next.

tn.ref: In the second month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month
tn.text: seventh day of the month** - "On the twenty seventh day of the second month." This may refer to the second month of the Hebrew calendar, but this is uncertain. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_hebrewmonths]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
"the ground was completely dry" (UDB)
"Leave ... Take." Some translations read "Come out ... Bring out."  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])

tn.ref: every living creature of all flesh
tn.text: "every kind of living creature." See how "all flesh" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:06:11|6:12]].

This is an idiom. See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:28|1:28]]. God wanted the humans and animals to reproduce, so there would be many of them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Some translations read "Noah came out."  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])
"in groups of their own kinds"
"built an altar dedicated to Yahweh" or "built an altar for worshiping Yahweh." He may have built it with stones.
Here "clean" means that God allowed these animals to be used in sacrifice. Some animals were not used for sacrifices and were called "unclean."
Noah killed the animals and then completely burned them up as an offering to God. AT: "burned the animals as offerings to Yahweh"
This refers to the good smell of the roasted meat.
Here the word "heart" refers to God's thoughts and emotions.
"do very serious harm to the earth" (UDB)
This can be made more explicit: "because mankind is sinful." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: the inclination of their hearts is evil from childhood
tn.text: "from their earliest years they tend to do evil things" or "when they are young, they want to do evil things"
Here the word "hearts" refers to people's thoughts, emotions, desires, and will. AT: "their tendency" or "their habit"
This refers to an older child. AT: "from their youth"
"While the earth lasts" or "As long as the earth exists"
"the season for planting"

tn.ref: cold and heat, summer and winter
tn.text: These expressions both refer to two major weather conditions in the year. Translators may use local expressions. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
the hot, dry time of the year
the cool, wet or snowy time of the year
"will not cease to exist" or "will not cease to occur." This can be expressed in a positive manner. AT: "will continue" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

tn.ref: Be fruitful, multiply, and fill the earth
tn.text: This is God's blessing. He told Noah and his family to produce more humans like themselves, so that there would be many of them. The word "multiply" explains how they are to be "fruitful." See how you translated these commands in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:28|1:28]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: The fear of you and the dread of you will be upon every living animal ... and upon all the fish of the sea
tn.text: The writer speaks of fear and dread as if they were physical objects that could be upon the animals. AT: "Every living animal ... and all the fish of the sea will be dreadfully afraid of you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The fear of you and the dread of you
tn.text: The words "fear" and "dread" mean basically the same thing and emphasize how afraid the animals will be of mankind. AT: "A dreadful fear of you" or "A terrible fear of you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: every living animal on the earth
tn.text: This is the first of the four categories of animals that the writer lists, and not a summary of the rest of the animals that he mentions next.
This is a general term for things that fly. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:20|1:21]].

tn.ref: upon everything that goes low on the ground
tn.text: This includes all types of small animals. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:24|1:25]].

tn.ref: They are given into your hand
tn.text: The hand is a metonym for the control that the hand has. This can be made active. AT: "They are given into your control" or "I have put them under your control" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
God continues speaking to Noah and his sons.

Translators may add a footnote such as this: "The blood is a symbol for life." They may also add a footnote that says something like this: "God was commanding people not to eat meat while the blood was still in it. They had to drain out the blood first."
God continues speaking to Noah and his sons.
This contrasts man's blood with the blood of animals ([[:en:bible:notes:gen:09:01|9:4]]).

tn.ref: for your blood, the life that is in your blood
tn.text: It is implied that the blood is shed, or poured out, or spilled out. AT: "if anyone causes your blood to pour out" or "if anyone spills your blood" or "if anyone kills you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to physical life.
This payment refers to the death of the murderer, not to money. AT: "I will require anyone who kills you to pay"
Here the word "hand" refers to the one who is responsible for something happening. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: From the hand of every animal I will require it
tn.text: "I will require any animal that takes your life to pay"

tn.ref: From the hand of any man, that is, from the hand of one who has murdered his brother, I will require an accounting for the life of that man
tn.text: "I will require anyone who takes the life of another person to pay"
This phrase refers to the person in a very personal way. AT: "From that very man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "brother" is used as a general reference to relatives, such as members of the same tribe, clan, or people group.

tn.ref: Whoever sheds man's blood, by man will his blood be shed
tn.text: The shedding of blood is a metaphor for killing someone. This means that if a person murders someone, someone else must kill the murderer. However, "blood" is very significant in this passage and should be used in the translation if possible. Translate "sheds blood" with words that indicate a major loss of blood that causes death. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: for it was in the image of God that he made man
tn.text: "because God made people to be like him" or "because I made people in my own image"

This is God's blessing. He told Noah and his family to produce more humans like themselves, so that there would be many of them. The word "multiply" explains how they are to be "fruitful." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:28|1:28]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Then God spoke to Noah and to his sons with him
tn.text: God was already speaking to them. This phrase marks a change in what God was going to speak about. AT: "God continued speaking to Noah and his sons" or "Then God went on to say"
This phrase is used in English to mark the change from God talking about what Noah and his sons must do to talking about what God would do.
"make a covenant between you and me." Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:06:18|6:18]].
God continues speaking to Noah and his sons.

tn.ref: I hereby confirm my covenant with you
tn.text: "By saying this, I make my covenant with you." See how similar words are translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:06:18|6:18]].
Possible meanings are 1) all human beings or 2) all physical beings, including humans and animals. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Never again will there be a flood to destroy the earth
tn.text: "There will never again be a flood that destroys the earth." There would be floods, but they would not destroy the whole earth.
This means a reminder of something that was promised.
The covenant applies to Noah and his family and also to all generations that follow.
God continues speaking to Noah and his sons.
"Whenever." It is something that would happen many times.

tn.ref: I will call to mind my covenant
tn.text: This does not mean that God would first forget. AT: "I will think about my covenant"
The word "you" is plural. God was speaking to Noah and Noah's sons.

tn.ref: every living creature of all flesh
tn.text: "every kind of living being"

Possible meanings are 1) all human beings or 2) all physical beings, including humans and animals. See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:06:11|6:12]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
God continues speaking to Noah and his sons.
"so that I will remember" or "so that I will think about"

tn.ref: between God and every living creature
tn.text: God is speaking here. AT: "between me and every living creature"

tn.ref: every living creature of all flesh
tn.text: "every kind of living being." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:09:14|9:15]].
God was already talking to Noah. This phrase marks the final part of what God was saying. AT: "God finished by saying to Noah" or "So God said to Noah"
Verses 18-19 introduce the three sons of Noah, who will be an important part of the next story.
Ham was Canaan's true father.
"man of the soil"
"drank too much wine"
The text does not specify how much of Noah's body was uncovered as he lay drunk. His sons' reactions show us that it was shameful.
This refers to Noah.
In verses 25-27 Noah pronounced a curse on Ham's son and blessings on Ham's brothers. What Noah said about them also applied to their descendants, as shown in the UDB.
Alternate phrases in these verses are indented to show that this is poetry. If you can, format these verses as they are formatted here to show your readers that this is poetry.
"became sober"

"I curse Canaan" or "May bad things happen to Canaan"
This was one of Ham's sons. AT: "Ham's son Canaan"

tn.ref: a servant to his brothers' servants
tn.text: "the lowest servant of his brothers" or "the least important servant of his brothers"
This could refer either to Canaan's brothers or to his relatives in general.
If you can, format these verses as they are formatted here to show your readers that this is poetry.

tn.ref: May Yahweh, the God of Shem, be blessed
tn.text: "Praised be Yahweh, the God of Shem," or "Yahweh, the God of Shem, is worthy of praise" or "I praise Yahweh, the God of Shem" (UDB)
"And let Canaan be Shem's servant." This includes Canaan's and Shem's descendants.

tn.ref: May God extend the territory of Japheth
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "May God make Japheth's territory larger" (UDB) or 2) "May God cause Japheth to have many descendants."

tn.ref: and let him make his home in the tents of Shem
tn.text: "and let him leave peacefully with Shem." This includes Japheth's and Shem's descendants.
"Let Canaan be Japheth's servant." This includes Canaan's and Japheth's descendants.

tn.ref: These were the descendants of the sons of Noah
tn.text: "This is the account of Noah's sons." This sentence introduces the account of Noah's descendants in Genesis 10:1-11:9.

tn.ref: From these the coastland peoples separated and went into their lands
tn.text: "Javan's sons and descendants separated and moved to the coastlands and islands"
This refers to people who lived along the coast and on the islands.
"their homelands." These are the places that the people moved to and lived in.

tn.ref: every one with its own language
tn.text: "Each people group spoke its own language" or "The people groups divided themselves according to their languages"
Mizraim is the Hebrew name for "Egypt."
Possible meanings are 1) "mighty warrior" or 2) "mighty man" or 3) "powerful ruler."
Possible meanings are 1) "in Yahweh's sight" or 2) "with Yahweh's help"

tn.ref: That is why it is said
tn.text: This introduces a proverb. Your language may introduce proverbs and sayings in a different way. AT: "This is the reason people say (See: [["en:ta:workbench:translate:writingstyles_proverbs]])
Possible meanings are 1) the first centers he developed or 2) the important cities.
"Nimrod went into Assyria"
The list of Noah's descendants continues.
Mizraim was one of Ham's sons. His descendants became the people of Egypt. Mizraim is the Hebrew name for Egypt.
These names refer to larger groups of people that descended from Canaan.
"territory" or "border of their territory"

tn.ref: from Sidon, in the direction of Gerar, as far as Gaza
tn.text: The direction south can be stated explicitly if needed. AT: "from Sidon city in the north as far south as Gaza town, which is near Gerar"(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: as one goes toward Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboiim, as far as Lasha
tn.text: The direction "east" or "inland" can be stated explicitly if needed. AT: "then east toward Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboiim towns, as far as Lasha" (See: Assumed Knowledge and Implicit Information]])

tn.ref: These were the sons of Ham
tn.text: The word "these" refers to the people and people groups who were listed in verses [[:en:bible:notes:gen:10:06|6-19]].
"broken up according to their different languages"
"in their homelands"

"These" here refers to the sons of Joktan.
"The land they controlled" or "The land they lived in"

tn.ref: These were the sons of Shem
tn.text: The word "these" refers to the descendants of Shem ([[:en:bible:notes:gen:10:21|10:21-29]]).
This refers back to all the people listed in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:10:01|10:1-31]].
"listed by"

tn.ref: From these the nations separated and went over the earth
tn.text: "From these clans the nations divided and spread over the earth" or "These clans divided from each other and formed the nations of the earth"
This can be stated clearly or more explicitly. AT: "after the flood destroyed the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This word shows that the writer is beginning a new part of the story.

These are two different names and they are spelled differently in Hebrew. One refers to a person and the other refers to a city. (The "h" sound in the city's name is louder than the "h" sound in the person's name.) You might choose to spell them differently in your language to show this.

The word "name" represents the person's reputation. AT: "and make you famous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

"payment." This refers to the payment a person deserves. Two possible meanings are 1) "I am all that you need" or 2) "I will give you all you need."

"surrounded him"
