tn.ref: you will go to your fathers
tn.text: This is a polite way of saying "you will die." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
The word "fathers" is a synecdoche for all ancestors. AT: "ancestors" or "ancestral fathers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: you will be buried in a good old age
tn.text: "you will be very old when you die and your family buries your body"
Here one generation refers to a lifespan of 100 years. "After four hundred years"
"your descendants will come back here." Abraham's descendants would come to the land where Abram was then living, the land that Yahweh had promised to give to him.

tn.ref: has not yet reached its limit
tn.text: "is not yet complete" or "will get much worse before I punish them"
The word "behold" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows.

tn.ref: a smoking fire pot and a flaming torch passed between the pieces
tn.text: God did this to show Abram that he was making a covenant with him.
"passed through between the two rows of animal pieces"
In this covenant God promises to bless Abram, and he will continue to bless him as long as Abram follows him.
By saying this, God was giving the land to Abram's descendants. God was doing this then, but the descendants would not go into the land until many years later.
"the large river, the Euphrates." These are two ways of referring to the same river.

tn.ref: the Kenites, the Kenizzites, the Kadmonites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Rephaites, the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Girgashites, and the Jebusites
tn.text: These are the names of groups of people who lived in that land. God would allow Abraham's descendants to conquer these people and take their land. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This word is used in English to introduce a new part of the story and background information about Sarai. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"slave-girl." This type of slave would serve the woman of the household.
"from giving birth to children"

tn.ref: I will have children by her
tn.text: "I will build my family through her"

tn.ref: Abram listened to the voice of Sarai
tn.text: "Abram did what Sarai said"

tn.ref: she looked with contempt on her mistress
tn.text: "she despised her mistress" or "she thought that she was more valuable than her mistress"
Here this refers to Sarai. A mistress has authority over her slave. AT: "her owner" or "Sarai"
"This injustice against me"
"is your responsibility" or "is your fault"

tn.ref: I gave my servant woman into your embrace
tn.text: Sarai used the word "embrace" here to refer to him sleeping with her. AT: "I gave you my servant so that you would sleep with her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: I was despised in her eyes
tn.text: This can be active. AT: "she hated me" or "she began to hate me" or "she thought she was better than me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Let Yahweh judge between me and you
tn.text: "I want Yahweh to say whether this is my fault or your fault" or "I want Yahweh to decide which one of us is right." The phrase "to judge between" means to decide which person is right in a dispute between them.
"Listen to me" or "Pay attention"
"under your authority"
"Sarai treated Hagar very badly"
"and Hagar fled from Sarai"

Possible meanings are 1) Yahweh made himself look like an angel or 2) this was one of Yahweh's angels or 3) this was a special messenger from God (some scholars think it was Jesus). Since the phrase is not well understood, it is best to simply translate it as "the angel of Yahweh" using the normal word that you use for "angel."
The wilderness area she went to was a desert. AT: "desert"
This was the name of a place south of Canaan and east of Egypt.
Here this refers to Sarai. A mistress has authority over her slave. AT: "my owner." See how "her mistress" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:16:01|16:4]].

tn.ref: The angel of Yahweh said to her
tn.text: "The angel of Yahweh said to Hagar"
See the note about this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:16:07|16:7]].
Sarai. See how "her mistress" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:16:01|16:4]].

tn.ref: the angel of Yahweh said to her, "I
tn.text: When he said "I," he was referring to Yahweh. When translating what is in the quote, do it as the angel of Yahweh did and use the word "I" when referring to Yahweh.

tn.ref: I will greatly multiply your descendants
tn.text: "I will give you very many descendants"
"so many that no one will be able to count them"
See the note about this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:16:07|16:7]].
"Look" or "Listen" or "Pay attention"
"give birth to a son"
"you will name him." The word "you" refers to Hagar.
Translators may add a footnote that says "The name 'Ishmael' means 'God has heard.'"
She has been afflicted by distress and suffering.

tn.ref: He will be a wild donkey of a man
tn.text: This was not an insult. It may mean that Ishmael would be independent and strong like a wild donkey. AT: "He will be like a wild donkey among men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He will be hostile against every man
tn.text: "He will be every man's enemy"

tn.ref: every man will be hostile to him
tn.text: "everyone will be his enemy"
This can also mean "he will live in hostility with."
"relatives" or "kin"
"Yahweh, because he spoke to her"

tn.ref: Do I really continue to see, ... me?
tn.text: Hagar used this rhetorical question to express her amazement that she was still alive even after she met God. People expected that if they met God, they would die. AT: "I am surprised that I am still alive, ... me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Therefore the well was called Beerlahairoi
tn.text: Translators may add a footnote that says "Beerlahairoi means 'the well of the living one who sees me.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: behold, it is between Kadesh and Bered
tn.text: The word "behold" here draws attention to the fact that the well was in a place that the author and his readers knew. AT: "in fact, it is between Kadesh and Bered" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Hagar's return to Sarai and Abram is implict. You can make this more explicit. AT: "So Hagar went back and gave birth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: named his son, whom Hagar bore
tn.text: "named his son by Hagar" or "named his and Hagar's son"

This introduces background information about Abram's age when these things happened. Your language may have a special way to mark background information. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
This means "gave birth to Abram's son, Ishmael." The focus is on Abram having a son.

tn.ref: When Abram was ninety-nine years old
tn.text: nine years old** - This phrase is used here to mark the beginning of a new part of the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.
"the all-powerful God" or "the God who has all power"
Walking is a metaphor for living, and "before me" or "in my presence" here is a metaphor for obedience. AT: "Live the way I want you to" or "Obey me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"If you do this, then I will confirm"
"I will give my covenant" or "I will make my covenant"
In this covenant God promises to bless Abram, but he also requires Abram to obey him.
"greatly increase the number of your descendants" or "give you very many descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Abram bowed low with his face to the ground
tn.text: "Abram threw himself face down on the ground" or "Abraham immediately lay down with his face to the ground." He did this to show that he respected God and would obey him.
God used this phrase to introduce what he would do for Abram as part of his covenant with Abram.

tn.ref: behold, my covenant is with you
tn.text: The word "behold" here says that what comes next is certain: "my covenant is certainly with you."

tn.ref: the father of a multitude of nations
tn.text: "the father of a great number of nations" or "the one after whom many nations name themselves"
Translators may add the following footnote: The name "Abram" means "exalted father" and the name "Abraham" sounds like "father of a multitude."

tn.ref: I will make you exceedingly fruitful
tn.text: "I will cause you to have very many descendants"

tn.ref: I will make nations of you
tn.text: "I will cause your descendants to become nations"
"among your descendants there will be kings" or "some of your descendants will be kings"
God continues speaking to Abraham.
"for each generation"
"as a covenant that will last forever"

tn.ref: to be God to you and to your descendants after you
tn.text: "to be your God and your descendants' God" or "covenant"
"Canaan, as an everlasting possession" or "Canaan, to possess forever"
God uses this phrase to introduce what Abram would have to do as part of God's covenant with him.
"observe my covenant" or "honor my covenant" or "obey my covenant"
"This is a requirement of my covenant" or "This is part of my covenant." This sentence introduces the part of the covenant that Abram must do.

tn.ref: Every male among you must be circumcised
tn.text: This can be stated in an active form. AT: "You must circumcise every male among you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This refers to human males.

tn.ref: You must be circumcised in the flesh of your foreskin
tn.text: Some communities may prefer a less descriptive expression such as "You must be circumcised." If your translation of "be circumcised" already includes the word for "foreskin", you do not need to repeat it. This can be made active. AT: "You must circumcise every male among you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"the sign that shows that the covenant exists"

Possible meanings are 1) "the sign" or 2) "a sign." The first means that there was one sign, and the second means that there may have been more than one sign. Here the word "sign" means a reminder of something that God had promised.
God continues speaking to Abraham.
"Every human male"
"in every generation"

tn.ref: him who is bought with money
tn.text: This refers to slaves. This can be stated in active form. AT: "any male that you buy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: my covenant will be in your flesh
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "you will mark my covenant in your flesh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"as a permanent covenant." Because it was marked in flesh, no one could easily erase it.

tn.ref: uncircumcised male who is not circumcised
tn.text: This can be stated in active form, and you may leave out words that will give wrong meaning in your language. AT: "male whom you have not circumcised" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Any uncircumcised male ... foreskin will be cut off from his people
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "I will cut off any uncircumcised male ... foreskin from his people" or 2) "I want you to cut off any uncircumcised male ... foreskin from his people."
Possible meanings are 1) "killed" or 2) "sent away from the community." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
"He has not obeyed the rules of my covenant." This is the reason that he would be cut off from his people.
The words "As for" introduce the next person God talks about.

tn.ref: I will give you a son by her
tn.text: "I will make her bear a son for you"

tn.ref: she will become the mother of nations
tn.text: "she will be the ancestor of many nations" (UDB) or "her descendants will become nations"

tn.ref: Kings of peoples will come from her
tn.text: "Kings of peoples will descend from her" or "Some of her descendants will be kings of peoples"
"thought to himself" or "said to himself silently"

tn.ref: Can a child be born to a man who is a hundred years old?
tn.text: Abraham used this rhetorical question because he did not believe that this could happen. AT: "Surely a man who is a hundred years old cannot father a child!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: And can Sarah, who is ninety years old, bear a son?
tn.text: Again Abraham used a rhetorical question because he did not believe this could happen. The phrase "who is ninety years old" tells why Abraham did not believe that Sarah could bear a son. AT: "And Sarah is ninety years old. Could she bear a son?" or "And Sarah is ninety years old. Surely she could not bear a son!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and  [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_distinguish]])

tn.ref: Oh that Ishmael might live before you
tn.text: "Please let Ishmael inherit the covenant that you have made with me" or "Perhaps Ishmael could receive your covenant blessing." Abraham suggested something that he believed really could happen.

tn.ref: No, but Sarah your wife will bear
tn.text: God said this to correct Abraham's belief that Sarah could not have a son.
The word "you" refers to Abraham.
The words "As for" show that God is switching from talking about the baby that would be born to talking about Ishmael.
"Look" or "Listen" or "Pay attention to what I am about to tell you"
This is an idiom that means "will cause him to have many children." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"and I will cause him to have many descendants"
"chiefs" or "rulers." These leaders are not the twelve sons and grandsons of Jacob that will lead the twelve tribes of Israel.

tn.ref: But my covenant I will establish with Isaac
tn.text: God returns to talking about his covenant with Abraham and emphasizes that he would fulfill his promise with Isaac, not with Ishmael.

tn.ref: When he had finished talking with him
tn.text: "When God had finished talking with Abraham"
"God left Abraham"

tn.ref: every male among the men of Abraham's household
tn.text: "every human male in Abraham's household" or "every male person in Abraham's household." It refers to human males of all ages: babies, boys, and men.

tn.ref: including those born into the household and those bought with money from a foreigner
tn.text: "This includes those who were born in his household and those he had bought from foreigners"

tn.ref: those bought with money from a foreigner
tn.text: This refers to servants or slaves.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "those whom he had bought" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This was the name of the man who owned the oak trees.
"at the opening of the tent" or "at the entrance of the tent"
"hottest time of day"

tn.ref: He looked up and, behold, he saw three men standing
tn.text: "He looked up and saw, and behold, three men were standing"
"suddenly." The word "behold" here shows us that what follows was surprising to Abraham.
"nearby" or "there." They were near him, but far enough away for him to run to them.
This means to bend over to humbly express respect and honor toward someone.
This is a title of respect. Possible meanings are 1) Abraham knew that one of these men was God or 2) Abraham knew that these men came on behalf of God.
Abraham is speaking to one of the men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"please do not keep on going"
"me." Abraham refers to himself this way in order to show respect to his guest.

tn.ref: Let a little water be brought
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Let me bring you some water" or "My servant will bring you some water" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: a little water ... a little food
tn.text: "some water ... some food." Saying "little" was a polite way of showing generosity. Abraham would give them more than enough water and food.
This custom helped tired travelers to refresh themselves after walking long distances.
Abraham speaks to all three of the men, so "you" and "your" are plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
about 22 liters (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bvolume]])
This bread was probably cooked quickly on a hot stone. It may have been flat or round like small loaves or rolls.
"the servant hurried"
"to cut it up and roast it"
This refers to the solid part of fermented milk. It may have been yogurt or cheese.

tn.ref: the calf that had been prepared
tn.text: "the roasted calf"
"before the three visitors"
"Then they said to Abraham"

tn.ref: He said, "I will certainly return to you
tn.text: The word "He" refers to the man whom Abraham called "Lord" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:18:03|18:3]].
"when this same season comes next year" or "about this time next year" (UDB)
The word "see" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows.
"at the opening of the tent" or "at the entrance of the tent"

tn.ref: After I am worn-out and my master is old, will I now have this pleasure?
tn.text: out and my master is old, will I now have this pleasure?** - You may want to add "of having a baby" (UDB). Sarah used this rhetorical question because she did not believe that she could have a child. AT: "I cannot believe that I will experience the joy of having a child. My master is also too old" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This means "since my husband is also old."
This is a title of respect that Sarah gave to her husband Abraham.

tn.ref: Why did Sarah laugh and say, 'Will I really bear a child, when I am old'?
tn.text: God used this rhetorical question to show that he knew what Sarah was thinking and that he was not pleased with it. He repeats Sarah's rhetorical question ([[:en:bible:notes:gen:18:11|18:12]]) using different words. AT: "Sarah was wrong to laugh and say, 'I will not bear a child because I am too old!'"(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Is anything too hard for Yahweh?
tn.text: "Is there anything that Yahweh cannot do?" Yahweh speaks of himself as if he were speaking of someone else to remind Abraham that he, Yahweh, is great and can do anything. AT: "There is nothing that I, Yahweh, cannot do!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: At the time appointed by me, in the spring
tn.text: "At the time I have appointed, which is in the spring"

tn.ref: Then Sarah denied it and said
tn.text: "The Sarah denied it by saying"
"Yahweh replied"
"Yes, you did laugh." This means "No, that is not true; you did in fact laugh."

tn.ref: to see them on their way
tn.text: "to send them on their way" or "to say 'Farewell' to them" (UDB). It was polite to go some distance with guests as they were leaving.

tn.ref: Should I hide from Abraham what I am about to do ... him?
tn.text: God used this rhetorical question to say that he was going to talk to Abraham about something very important and that it was best for him to do so. AT: "I should not and will not hide from Abraham what I am about to do ... him." or "I should and will tell Abraham what I am about to do ... him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"I should not ... do. This is because ... him"

tn.ref: all the nations of the earth will be blessed in him
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will bless all the nations of the earth through Abraham" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"will be blessed because of Abraham" or "will be blessed because I have blessed Abraham." For translating "in him" see how you translated "through you" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:12:01|12:3]].
"that he will direct" or "so that he will command"

tn.ref: to keep the way of Yahweh ... Yahweh may bring ... he has said
tn.text: Yahweh is speaking about himself as if he were another person. AT: "to obey what I, Yahweh, require ... I, Yahweh, may bring ... I have said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: to keep the way of Yahweh
tn.text: "to obey the commands of Yahweh"
"by doing righteousness and justice." This tells how to keep the way of Yahweh.

tn.ref: so that Yahweh may bring upon Abraham what he has said to him
tn.text: "so that Yahweh may bless Abraham just as he said he would." This refers to the covenant promise to bless Abraham and make him a great nation.

tn.ref: the outcry against Sodom and Gomorrah is so great
tn.text: This can be reworded so that the abstract noun "outcry" is expressed as the verb "accuse." AT: "so many people have been accusing the people of Sodom and Gomorrah of doing evil things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"they have sinned so much"

tn.ref: I will now go down there
tn.text: "I will now go down to Sodom and Gomorrah"
"go down there to find out" or "go down there to decide"

tn.ref: see the outcry ... that has come to me
tn.text: Yahweh speaks as if he knew about this matter because he had heard the cries and accusations coming from the people who had suffered. This can be reworded so that the abstract noun "outcry" is expressed as the verb "accuse." AT: "as wicked as those who are accusing them say that they are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"If they are not as wicked as the outcry suggests"
"went out from Abraham's camp"
"Abraham and Yahweh remained together"
"approached Yahweh" or "stepped closer to Yahweh"
Abraham speaks of destroying people as if it were sweeping dirt with a broom. AT: "destroy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"the righteous people with the wicked people"
Abraham continues talking to Yahweh.
"Suppose there are"

tn.ref: Will you sweep it away and not spare the place for the sake of the fifty righteous that are there?
tn.text: Abraham was hoping that Yahweh would say, "I will not sweep it away." AT: "I think you would not sweep it away. Instead, you would spare the place for the sake of the fifty righteous that are there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"destroy it." Abraham speaks of destroying people as if it were sweeping dirt with a broom. AT: "destroy the people who live there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: and not spare the place for the sake of the fifty righteous that are there?
tn.text: Abraham was hoping that God would say "I will spare the place for the sake of the fifty righteous people there."
"let the people live"
"because of"

tn.ref: Far be it from you to do such a thing
tn.text: "I would never want you to do something like that" or "You should not want to do something like that" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"such a thing as killing" or "such a thing, that is, killing"

tn.ref: the righteous should be treated the same as the wicked
tn.text: This can be stated in active from. AT: "you should treat the righteous the same way you treat the wicked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Will not the Judge of all the earth do what is just?
tn.text: Abraham used this rhetorical question to say what he expected God to do. AT: "The Judge of all the earth will certainly do what is just" or "Since you are the Judge of all the earth, you will surely do what is right!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
God is often referred to as a judge because he is the one perfect judge who makes the final decisions about what is right or wrong.
The phrase "Look" here draws attention to the surprising information that follows.
"Pardon me for being so bold as to speak to you" or "Excuse me for daring to speak"
Abraham shows his respect to Yahweh by speaking to Yahweh as if he were speaking to someone else. AT: "to you, my Lord" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

This metaphor describes Abraham as a human being, who will die and whose body will turn into to dust and ashes. AT: "only a mortal man" or "as unimportant as dust and ashes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"only forty-five righteous people"
"if there are five fewer righteous people"
"I will not destroy Sodom"
"Abraham spoke to Yahweh"

tn.ref: if there are forty found there
tn.text: This means "if you find forty righteous people in Sodom and Gomorrah."
"Yahweh answered"

tn.ref: I will not do it for the forty's sake
tn.text: "I will not destroy the cities if I find forty righteous people there"
"thirty righteous people" or "thirty good people"
The phrase "Look" here draws attention to the surprising information that follows.
"Pardon me for being so bold as to speak to you" or "Excuse me for daring to speak." See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:18:27|18:27]].
"twenty righteous people" or "twenty good people"

tn.ref: Perhaps ten will be found there
tn.text: "Perhaps you will find ten righteous people there"
"ten righteous people" or "ten good people"
"And Yahweh answered"
"if I find ten righteous people there"
"Yahweh departed" or "Yahweh left" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Genesis 18 says that two men went to Sodom. Here we learn that they are really angels. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:gen:18:22|18:22]])

"the entrance to the city of Sodom." The city had a wall around it, and people had to go through a gate to get into it. This was a very important place in a city. Important people often spent time there.

tn.ref: bowed down with his face to the ground
tn.text: He put his knees on the ground then touched his forehead and nose to the ground.
This was a term of respect Lot used for the angels.

tn.ref: I urge you to turn aside into your servant's house
tn.text: "Please come and stay in your servant's house"
Lot refers to himself as their servant in order to show them respect. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
People liked to wash their feet after traveling.
"wake up early"

When the two angels said this, they were referring only to themselves, not to Lot. The two of them planed to spend the night in the square. Some languages would use the exclusive form of "we" here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
This is a public, outdoor place in the town.
"they turned and went with him"
"before the people in Lot's house lay down to go to sleep"

tn.ref: the men of the city, the men of Sodom
tn.text: "the men of the city, that is, the men of Sodom" or just "the men of the city of Sodom"
"Lot's house"
"from the youngest to the oldest." This means "men of all ages" and refers to the men of Sodom who were surrounding Lot's house.
"that went into your house"
"engage in sex with them." Your language may have a more polite way of saying this. AT: "know them intimately or sexually" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
"behind him" or "after he went through"
"I plead with you, my brothers"
Lot spoke in a friendly way to the men of the city hoping that they would listen to him. AT: "my friends" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"do not do something so wicked" or "do not do such a wicked thing"
"Pay attention" or "Look here"
"have not engaged in sex with." Your language may have a more polite way of saying this. AT: "have not known" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: whatever is good in your eyes
tn.text: "whatever you desire" or "whatever you think is right"

tn.ref: under the shadow of my roof
tn.text: The two men were guests in Lot's home, so he needed to protect them. The word "roof" is a synecdoche for the whole house and a metaphor for Lot protecting them. AT: "into my house, and God expects me to protect them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Step aside!" or "Get out of our way!" (UDB)

tn.ref: This one came here to live as a foreigner
tn.text: "This one came here as an outsider" or "This foreigner came to live here"
"Lot." The men are speaking to each other. If this would be unclear in your language, you may have the men speak to Lot here, as in UDB.

tn.ref: and now he has become our judge
tn.text: "and now he thinks he has the right to tell us what is right and what is wrong" or "but we are not going to allow him to stop us from doing what we want to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"and even though he has no good reason to, he" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"Because you are telling us that what we are doing is wrong, we"

tn.ref: we will deal worse with you than with them
tn.text: The men are angry that Lot said, "Do not act so wickedly" ([[:en:bible:notes:gen:19:06|19:7]]), so they are threatening to act more wickedly than Lot had feared at first. AT: "we will act more wickedly with you than we will with them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: They pressed hard against the man, against Lot, and came near to break down the door
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "They kept coming closer to the man, to Lot, until they were close enough to break down the door" or 2) they physically pushed Lot up against the wall or door of the house and were about to break the door down.
This is two ways of referring to Lot.
"But Lot's two guests" or "But the two angels"

tn.ref: the men reached out their hands and brought ... them and shut
tn.text: Your language may need to add that the men opened the door first. AT: 'the men opened the door far enough so they could reach out their hands and pull ... them, and then they shut" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Lot's visitors struck with blindness the men
tn.text: The phrase "struck with blindness" is a metaphor; the visitors did not physically hit the men. AT: "Lot's visitors blinded the men" or "they took away their sight" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

"men of all ages." This merism emphasizes that the visitors blinded all the men. This could indicate social standing rather than age. AT: "both small and great"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
"Then the two men said" or "Then the angels said"

tn.ref: Do you have anyone else here?
tn.text: "Are there any other members of your family in the city?" or "Do you have any other family members in this place?"

tn.ref: whoever you have in the city
tn.text: "any other members of your family living in this city"

The word "we" here is exclusive. Only the two angels would destroy the city; Lot would not destroy it. If your language has an exclusive form of "we," use it here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: the accusations against it before Yahweh have become so loud
tn.text: This can be reworded so that the abstract noun "accusations" is expressed as a verb. AT: "so many people have been telling Yahweh that the people of this city are doing evil things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and how similar words are translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:18:20|18:20]])
"So Lot left the house"

tn.ref: his sons-in-law, the men who had promised to marry his daughters
tn.text: in-law, the men who had promised to marry his daughters** - The phrase "the men who had promised to marry his daughters" explains what "sons-in-law" means here. AT: "the men who were going to marry his daughters" or "his daughters' fiancés" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"Just before the sun came up"
"Go now"

tn.ref: you are not swept away in the punishment of the city
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "so Yahweh does not also destroy you when he punishes the people of this city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: not swept away in the punishment
tn.text: God destroying the people of the city is spoken of as if a person were sweeping away dust. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "city" stands for the people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"But Lot hesitated" or "But Lot did not start to leave"
"So the two men grabbed" or "So the angels grabbed"

"had compassion on Lot." Yahweh is described as being "merciful" because he was sparing the lives of Lot and his family instead of destroying them when he destroyed the people of Sodom for the wrong they had done.

tn.ref: When they had brought them out
tn.text: "When the two men had brought Lot's family out"
This is a way of telling them to run so that they do not die. AT: "Run away and save your lives!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "at the city" is understood. AT: "Do not look back at the city" or "Do not look back at Sodom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
This means the plain of the Jordan River. This refers to the general region of the Jordan River.

tn.ref: so you are not swept away
tn.text: It is understood that they would swept away with the people of the city. This can be stated in active form. AT: "or else God will destroy you along with the people of the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
God destroying the people of the city is spoken of as if a person were sweeping away dust. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Your servant has found favor in your sight
tn.text: To be pleased with someone is spoken as if "favor" were an object that is found. Also, "sight" is a metonym that represents a person's thoughts or opinions. AT: "You have been pleased with me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Lot was showing respect by referring to himself as "your servant." AT: "I, your servant, have" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: you have shown me great kindness in saving my life
tn.text: The abstract noun "kindness" can be stated as "kind." AT: "you have been very kind to me by saving my life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: I cannot escape to the mountains, because the disaster will overtake me, and I will die
tn.text: Being unable to get far enough away from Sodom when God destroys the city is spoken of as if "disaster" is a person that will chase and catch up with Lot. AT: "My family and I will certainly die when God destroys the people of Sodom, because the mountains are too far away for us to get there safely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: my life ... I cannot escape ... overtake me, and I will die
tn.text: It is implied that Lot's family would die along with him. AT: "our lives ... we cannot escape ... overtake us, and we will die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: let me escape there (is it not a little one?), and my life will be saved
tn.text: Lot used this rhetorical question to get the angels to notice that the city really is a small one. AT: "let me escape there. You can see how small it is. If you let us go there we will live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Lot's full request can be made explicit. AT: "instead of destroying that city, let me escape there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

It is implied that the lives of Lot's family will be saved along with his. This can also be stated in active form. AT: "so that we will live" or "so that we will survive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I am granting this request also
tn.text: "I will do what you have asked"
This can be made more explicit. AT: "cannot destroy the other cities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Translators may add a footnote that says "The name Zoar sounds like the Hebrew word that means 'little.' Lot called this town 'little' in Genesis 19:20."

tn.ref: The sun had risen upon the earth
tn.text: "The sun had risen over the earth." The phrase "upon the earth" can be left implicit as it is in the UDB where it is not translated. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is implied that Lot's family is with him. AT: "when Lot and his family arrived at Zoar" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Yahweh rained down upon Sodom and Gomorrah sulfur and fire from Yahweh out of the sky
tn.text: The phrase "from Yahweh" stands for God's power to cause the sulfur and fire to fall on the city. AT: "Yahweh caused sulfur and fire to fall from the sky onto Sodom and Gomorrah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These two words are used together to describe one object. AT: "burning sulfur" or "fiery rain" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hendiadys]])
This refers primarily to Sodom and Gomorrah, but also to three other towns.
"the people who lived in the cities"

tn.ref: she became a pillar of salt
tn.text: "she became like a statue of salt" or "her body became like a tall stone of salt." Because she disobeyed the angel who told them not to look back at the city, God caused her to become something like a statue made out of rock salt.
The word "behold" draws attention to the surprising information that follows.

tn.ref: like the smoke of a furnace
tn.text: This shows that it was a very large amount of smoke. AT: "like the smoke from a very large fire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Verse 29 is a summary of this chapter.

This tells why God rescued Lot. To "call to mind" is a way of saying "remember." This does not imply that God forgot about Abraham. It means he considered Abraham and had mercy on him. AT: "God thought about Abraham and had mercy on him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: out of the midst of the destruction
tn.text: "away from the destruction" or "away from danger"

tn.ref: Lot went up from Zoar to live in the mountains
tn.text: The phrase "went up from" is used because Lot went to a higher elevation in the mountains.
"Lot's first daughter" or "The older daughter" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"the younger daughter" or "her younger sister" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

tn.ref: according to the way of all the world
tn.text: Here "the world" stands for the people. AT: "as people everywhere do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
It can be made explicit that their goal was to get him drunk. AT: "drink wine until he gets drunk" (UDB) or "get drunk with wine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: so that we may extend our father's line
tn.text: This speaks about giving Lot descendants as if his family were a line that they are making longer. AT: "so that we can bear children who will be our father's descendants" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: he did not know when she lay down, nor when she arose
tn.text: "he did not know anything about it" or "he did not know that she had slept with him"

tn.ref: Let us make him drink wine ... nor when she arose
tn.text: Translate these phrases as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:19:31|19:32-33]].
It can be made explicit that their goal was to get him drunk. AT: "drink wine until he gets drunk" (UDB) or "get drunk with wine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: so that we may extend our father's line
tn.text: This speaks about giving Lot descendants as if his family were a line that they are making longer. AT: "so that we can bear children who will be our father's descendants" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He did not know when she lay down, nor when she arose
tn.text: "he did not know anything about it" or "he did not know that she had slept with him"
"became pregnant by their father" or "conceived children with their father"
"He is"
"the Moab people who are now living"
The word "today" refers to the time when the author of Genesis was living. The author was born and wrote this many years after Lot's family lived and died.
This is a male name. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"the descendants of Ammon" or "the Ammon people"
This is a desert region on the eastern border of Egypt. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: sent his men and they took Sarah
tn.text: "made his men go get Sarah and bring her to him"
"God appeared to Abimelech"
Here the word "behold" adds emphasis to what follows. "Listen to me" (UDB)
This is a strong way of saying the king will die. AT: "you will certainly die soon" or "I will kill you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"a married woman"
This word is used here to mark a change from the story to information about Abimelech. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

tn.ref: Abimelech had not come near her
tn.text: This is a polite way of saying he did not have sex with her. AT: "Abimelech had not slept with Sarah" or "Abimelech had not touched Sarah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
Here "nation" stands for the people. Abimelech is worried that God will punish not only him, but his people also. AT: "even a people who are innocent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Did he not himself say to me, 'She is my sister?' Even she herself said, 'He is my brother'
tn.text: This has quotations within a quotation. They can be stated as indirect quotations. AT: "Did he himself not tell me that she is his sister? Even she herself told me that he is her brother" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: Did he not himself say to me, 'She is my sister?'
tn.text: Abimelech used this rhetorical question to remind God of something God already knew. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "Abraham himself told me 'She is my sister.'" or "Abraham said that she is his sister." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Did he not himself say ... Even she herself
tn.text: The words "he himself" and "she herself" are used for emphasis to bring attention to Abraham and Sarah and to blame them for what happened. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])

tn.ref: I have done this in the integrity of my heart and the innocence of my hands
tn.text: Here "heart" stands for his thoughts or intentions. Also "hands" stands for his actions. AT: "I have done this with good intentions and actions" or "I have done this with no evil thoughts or actions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"God said to Abimelech"

tn.ref: in the integrity of your heart you did this
tn.text: Here "heart" stands for his thoughts or intentions. AT: "you did this with good intentions" or "you did this without evil intentions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is a euphemism for having sex with Sarah. AT: "to sleep with her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
"Abraham's wife"
"I will let you live"
"all of your people"

tn.ref: He told all these things to them
tn.text: "He told them everything that God had told him"

tn.ref: What have you done to us?
tn.text: Abimelech used this rhetorical question to accuse Abraham. AT: "You have done something bad to us!" or "Look what you have done to us!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The word "us" here is exclusive and does not include Abraham and Sarah. If your language uses an exclusive form of "we" or "us," use it here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: How have I sinned against you, that you have brought ... sin?
tn.text: Abimelech used this rhetorical question to remind Abraham that he had not sinned against Abraham. AT: "I have done nothing against you to cause you to bring ... sin." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: that you have brought on me and on my kingdom a great sin
tn.text: To cause someone to be guilty of sinning is spoken of as if "sin" was a thing  that could be placed on a person. AT: "that you should make me and my kingdom guilty of such a terrible sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "kingdom" stands for the people. AT: "on the people of my kingdom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: You have done to me that which ought not to be done
tn.text: "You should not have done this to me"

tn.ref: What prompted you to do this thing?
tn.text: "What caused you to do this?" or "Why did you do this?" What Abraham did can be stated explicitly. AT: "Why did you tell me that Sarah is your sister?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Because I thought, 'Surely there is no fear of God in this place, and they will kill me because of my wife.'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "Because I thought that since no one here fears God, someone may kill me so they can take my wife." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: no fear of God in this place
tn.text: Here "place" refers to the people. AT: "no one here in Gerar fears God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This means to deeply respect God and show that respect by obeying him.

tn.ref: Besides, she is indeed my sister
tn.text: "Also, it is true that Sarah is my sister" or "Also, Sarah really is my sister"

tn.ref: the daughter of my father, but not the daughter of my mother
tn.text: "we have the same father, but we have different mothers"
Verse 13 is a continuation of Abraham's answer to Abimelech.
Here "house" stands for Abraham's family. AT: "my father and the rest of my family" or "my father's household" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I said to her, 'You must show me this faithfulness as my wife: At every place where we go, say about me, "He is my brother."'
tn.text: This has quotations within quotations. They can be stated as indirect quotations. AT: "I said to Sarah that I wanted her to be faithful to me by telling people everywhere we go that I am her brother" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
"Abimelech brought some" (UDB)
"Abimelech said to Abraham"
Here and in verse 16 the word "look" adds emphasis to what follows.
This is a way of saying "I make all of my land available to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"Live wherever you want"
"1,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: It is to cover any offense against you in the eyes of all that are with you
tn.text: Giving money to prove to others that Sarah is innocent is spoken of as if he is placing a cover over an offense so no one can see it. AT: "I am giving this to him, so that those who are with you will know that you have done nothing wrong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "eyes" stands for a person's thoughts or opinion. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: before everyone, you are completely made right
tn.text: The passive phrase "made right" can be stated in active form. AT: "everyone will know that you are innocent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"totally unable to have children"
The full meaning can be stated explicitly. AT: "because Abimelech had taken Abraham's wife Sarah" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here the phrase "paid attention to" refers to Yahweh helping Sarah have a baby. AT: "Yahweh helped Sarah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"gave birth to Abraham's son"
"when Abraham was very old"

tn.ref: at the set time of which God had spoken to him
tn.text: "at the exact time that God had told him it would happen"

tn.ref: Abraham named his son, the one who had been born to him, whom Sarah bore to him, Isaac
tn.text: "Abraham named his newborn son, the one Sarah gave birth to, Isaac" or "Abraham named their newborn son Isaac"

tn.ref: Abraham circumcised his son Isaac when he was eight days old
tn.text: "When his son Isaac was eight days old, Abraham circumcised him"
"8 days" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"had commanded Abraham to do"
"100" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
Sarah was laughing because she was surprised and happy. This can be made explicit. AT: "God has caused me to laugh joyfully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
What people would hear can be stated explicitly. AT: "everyone who hears about what God has done for me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Who would have said to Abraham that Sarah would nurse children
tn.text: This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "No one would have ever said to Abraham that Sarah will nurse children" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This is a polite way of referring to breast-feeding babies. AT: "feed a baby her own milk" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: The child grew and ... Isaac was weaned
tn.text: "Wean" is a polite way of saying the child was finished with breast feeding. AT: "Isaac grew, and when he no longer needed his mother's milk, Abraham had a large feast" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: the son of Hagar the Egyptian, whom she had borne to Abraham
tn.text: The name of Hagar's son can be stated explicitly. AT: "Ishmael, the son of Hagar the Egyptian and Abraham" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It can be stated explicitly that he was jeering or laughing at Isaac. AT: "laughing at Isaac" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Sarah said to Abraham"
"send away" or "get rid of" (UDB)

tn.ref: this slave woman and her son
tn.text: This refers to Hagar and Ishmael. Sarah probably did not refer to them by name because she was angry with them.
"with my son Isaac"

tn.ref: This thing was very grievous to Abraham
tn.text: "Abraham was very unhappy about what Sarah said"
"because it was about his son." It is implied that this means his son, Ishmael. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Do not be grieved because of the lad, and because of your servant woman
tn.text: "Do not be upset about the boy and your handmaid"

tn.ref: Listen to her words in all she says to you about this matter
tn.text: Here "words" stands for what is said. AT: "Do everything that Sarah says to you about them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: it is through Isaac that your descendants will be named
tn.text: The phrase "will be named" means those born through Isaac are the ones God considers to be the descendants that he promised Abraham. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Isaac is the one who will be the forefather of the descendants I promised to give you" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I will also make the son of the servant woman into a nation
tn.text: The word "nation" means God will give him many descendants so that they become a great nation of people. AT: "I will make the servant woman's son also become the father of a great nation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Possible meanings are 1) this refers to food in general or 2) this refers to bread specifically. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"a bag of water." The water container was made out of animal skin.

tn.ref: When the water in the waterskin was gone
tn.text: "When the water bag was empty" or "When they had drank all of the water"

tn.ref: about the distance of a bowshot away
tn.text: This refers to the distance that a person could shoot an arrow with a bow. This is about 100 meters.

tn.ref: Let me not look upon the death of the child
tn.text: The abstract noun "death" can be stated as "die." AT: "I do not want to watch the boy die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: she lifted up her voice and wept
tn.text: Here "voice" stands for the sound of her crying. To "life up her voice" means to cry loudly. AT: "she cried out loudly and wept" or "she wept loudly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"the boy's voice." Here "voice" stands for the sound of the boy crying or speaking. AT: "the sound of Ishmael" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"a messenger from God" or "God's messenger"
Here "heaven" means the place where God lives.
"What is wrong" or "Why are you crying"

tn.ref: the voice of the lad where he is
tn.text: Here "voice" stands for the sound of the boy crying or speaking. AT: "the sound of the boy lying over there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"help the boy stand up"

tn.ref: I will make him into a great nation
tn.text: To make Ishmael into a great nation means God will give him many descendants who will become a great nation. AT: "I will make his descendants become a great nation" or "I will make him become the ancestor of a great nation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: God opened her eyes, and she saw
tn.text: God making Hagar aware of the well is spoken of as if he literally opened her eyes. AT: "God caused Hagar to see" or "God showed her" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"the container made of skin" or "the bag"
"the boy" or "Ishmael"
Here the phrase "was with" is an idiom that means God helped or blessed the boy. AT: "God guided the boy" or "God blessed the boy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"became very skilled at using a bow and arrows"
"found a wife"

tn.ref: It came about at that time
tn.text: This phrase marks the beginning of a new part of the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"commander of his army" (UDB)

tn.text: The phrase "Make sure" emphasizes the command that follows."Be careful not to take my son back there" or "You definitely must not take my son there"

tn.ref: who took me from my father's house
tn.text: Here "house" stands for the people in his family. AT: "who took me from my father and the rest of my family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: promised me with a solemn oath
tn.text: "swore an oath to me"

tn.ref: saying, 'To your offspring I will give this land,'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "saying that he would give this land to my offspring" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
The words "he" and "his" refer to Yahweh.
Verse 8 is a continuation of the instructions Abraham gave his servant.

tn.ref: But if the woman is not willing to follow you
tn.text: "But if the woman refuses to come with you." Abraham was answering the servant's question from [[:en:bible:notes:gen:24:05|24:5]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: you will be free from this oath of mine
tn.text: "you will be released from the oath you made to me." Not having to fulfill an oath is spoken of as if the person is free from an object to which he was bound. AT: "you will not have to do what you swore to me that you would do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: put his hand under the thigh of Abraham his master
tn.text: This was to show that he would certainly do what he was swearing to do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
"made an oath to him"
"concerning Abraham's request" or "that he would do what Abraham said"
The sentence starting with "He also took" gives additional information about what the servant took with him on the journey. He gathered them before he departed.

tn.ref: He also took with him all kinds of gifts from his master
tn.text: This means he also took many good things that his master wanted to give to the woman's family.
"set out and went" or "he left and went"
Possible meanings are 1) the city where Nahor lived" or 2) "the city called Nahor." If you can translate it without choosing a meaning, do so. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: He made the camels kneel down
tn.text: Camels are tall animals with long legs. He made them bend their legs and lower their bodies to the ground. "He made the camels lie down"
"water well" or "well" (UDB)
"get water" (UDB)
"Then the servant said"

tn.ref: grant me success today and show covenant faithfulness to my master Abraham
tn.text: You can state this with the connecting word "by." This makes clear how the servant wants God to show covenant faithfulness. AT: "Show covenant faithfulness to my master Abraham by granting me success today" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_connectingwords]])

"give me success." The servant wanted to find a good wife for Abraham's son. The abstract noun "success" can be stated as a verb. AT: "help me to succeed" or "make me able to do what I have come here to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: show covenant faithfulness to my master Abraham
tn.text: This is faithfulness because of the covenant that God made with Abraham. The abstract noun "faithfulness" can be stated as "be faithful." AT: "be faithful to my master Abraham because of your covenant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here the word "Look" adds emphasis to what follows.
"the spring" or "the well"

tn.ref: the daughters of the men of the city
tn.text: "the young women of the city"
"Let it happen this way" or "Make this happen"

tn.ref: When I say to a young woman, 'Please lower your pitcher so that I may drink,'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. This can be expressed with an indirect quote. AT: "When I ask a young woman to let me have a drink of water from her jar" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
The women carried the pitchers on their shoulder. She would have to lower it to give the man a drink.
a medium-size jar made of clay used for holding and pouring liquids

tn.ref: that you have shown covenant faithfulness to my master
tn.text: The abstract noun "faithfulness" can be stated as "been faithful." AT: "that you have been faithful to my master because of your covenant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This phrase is used here to mark where the action starts. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.
The word "behold" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows.
This is a medium-size jar made of clay used for holding and pouring liquids. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:24:12|24:14]].

tn.ref: Rebekah was born to Bethuel son of Milcah, the wife of Nahor, Abraham's brother
tn.text: "Rebekah's father was Bethuel. Bethuel's parents were Milcah and Nahor. Nahor was Abraham's brother"
Bethuel was Rebekah's father. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:22:20|22:22]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a man. See how you translated his name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:11:22|11:22]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Milcah was Nahor's wife and Bethuel's mother. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:11:29|11:29]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: She went down to the spring ... and came up
tn.text: The spring was somewhere lower in elevation than where the servant was standing.
"to meet the young woman"
"a little water"
This is a medium-size jar made of clay used for holding and pouring liquids. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:24:12|24:14]].
"sir." Here the woman uses this term of respect to refer to the man, though she is not his slave.

tn.ref: she quickly let down her pitcher on her hand
tn.text: "she quickly lowered her pitcher." She was carrying the pitcher on her shoulder. She had to lower it to get water for the servant.
"I will get water"

tn.ref: So she hurried and emptied her pitcher
tn.text: "So she quickly emptied her pitcher"
"the animals' water trough" (UDB). A trough is a long open container for holding water for animals to drink.
"The servant" (UDB)
"watched Rebekah" or "watched the young woman"
Learning something is often spoken of as if it were seeing. AT: "to know" (UDB) or "to determine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

"had fulfilled the purpose of his journey" or "had made his journey successful." You can make explicit what specifically the servant was trying to determine. AT: "was showing him the woman who would become Isaac's wife" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
You can state clearly the understood information. AT: "or not prospered his journey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: a gold nose ring weighing half a shekel
tn.text: "a gold nose ring that weighed six grams" (UDB). The weight indicates the value of the ring. AT: "an expensive gold nose ring" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])

tn.ref: two gold bracelets for her arms weighing ten shekels
tn.text: "two gold bracelets for her arms that weighed 110 grams." The weight shows their size and value. AT: "two large gold bracelets for her arms" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])
"Who is your father"

tn.ref: is there room in your father's house
tn.text: "is there a place in your father's house"
Apparently other men went on this journey with Abraham's servant. Here "us" refers to the servant and those traveling with him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]]
"to stay tonight" or "to stay for the night"
"Rebekah said" or "the young woman said"
"to the servant"

tn.ref: I am the daughter of Bethuel son of Milcah, whom she bore to Nahor
tn.text: "Bethuel is my father, and his parents are Milcah and Nahor"

tn.ref: We have plenty of both straw and feed
tn.text: It is understood that the straw and feed are for the camels. You can make clear this understood information. AT: "We have plenty of straw and feed for the camels" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: for you to spend the night
tn.text: "for you to stay tonight" or "where you can stay for the night"
Here "you" refers to the servant and those traveling with him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"the servant" (UDB)
This is a sign of humility before God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: has not forsaken his covenant faithfulness and his trustworthiness toward my master
tn.text: "has not stopped showing his covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness to my master." The abstract nouns "faithfulness" and "trustworthiness" can be stated as "to be faithful and trustworthy." AT: "has continued to be faithful and trustworthy because of his covenant with my master" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This can be stated in positive form. AT: "continues to show" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
"family" or "clan"

tn.ref: ran and told her mother's household
tn.text: Here "household" stands for all the people living in her mother's house. AT: "ran to the house and told her mother and everyone there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"everything that had just happened"

This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here the author tells background information about Rebekah. The author introduces her brother, Laban, to the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])

tn.ref: When he had seen the nose ring ... and when he had heard the words of Rebekah his sister
tn.text: These things happened before he ran out to the man. This tells why Laban ran out to the man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_events]])

tn.ref: when he had heard the words of Rebekah his sister, "This is what the man said to me,"
tn.text: This can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "when he had heard his sister Rebekah tell what the man had said to her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
"indeed." The word "behold" here adds emphasis to what follows.
"Come in" or "Enter"
"you whom Yahweh has blessed"
Here the word "you" refers to Abraham's servant. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

Laban used this question to invite Abraham's servant into his house. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "You do not need to stay outside." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: So the man came to the house
tn.text: The word "came" can be translated as "went." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])

It is not clear who did this work. This may be stated in active form. AT: "Laban's servants unloaded the camels" (UDB) or "the camels were unloaded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: The camels were given straw and feed, and water was provided
tn.text: This does not say who did the work. If you state this in active form use "Laban's servants" as the subject. AT: "Laban's servants gave straw and feed to the camels, and they provided water" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"for Abraham's servant and the men who were with him to wash their feet"
Here, the word "they" refers to Laban's family members or to the household servants.
"gave food to the servant"

tn.ref: said what I have to say
tn.text: "spoken my words" or "told you why I am here"
Here the word "he" refers to Abraham.
"become very wealthy"
The word "he" refers to Yahweh.
Abraham's servant continues speaking to Rebekah's family.

tn.ref: bore a son to my master
tn.text: "gave birth to a son"
"my master has given ... to his son"

tn.ref: My master made me swear, saying
tn.text: "My master made me swear that I would do what he told me to do. He said"

tn.ref: from the daughters of the Canaanites
tn.text: This refers to Canaanite females. AT: "from the Canaanite women" or "from the Canaanites"

tn.ref: in whose land I make my home
tn.text: "among whom I live." Here, "I" stands for Abraham and all of his family and servants. AT: "among whom we live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"to my own clan" (UDB)
Abraham's servant continues speaking to Rebekah's family.

tn.ref: Perhaps the woman will not follow me
tn.text: This is something that could possibly happen. AT: "What if the woman will not come back with me." or "What should I do if the woman will not come back with me?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
Serving Yahweh is spoken of as if Abraham were walking in Yahweh's presence. AT: "whom I serve" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"he will make your journey successful"
"family"

tn.ref: But you will be free from my oath if you come to my relatives and they will not give her to you. Then you will be free from my oath
tn.text: This is a hypothetical situation that Abraham did not think was likely to happen. Possible meanings are 1) "There is only one way for you to be free from my oath: if you come to my relatives and they will not give her to you, then you will be free from my oath" or, 2) building on verse 40, "If you go to my father's family and ask for a girl, you will have done what I told you to do. If they will not give her to you, then you will be free from the oath you swore to me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: you will be free from my oath
tn.text: "you will be released from the oath you made to me." Not having to fulfill an oath is spoken of as if the person is free from an object to which he was bound. AT: "you will not have to do what you swore to me that you would do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: if you come to my relatives
tn.text: Languages use the words come and go differently. AT: "if you arrive at my relatives' home" or "if you go to my relatives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])
Abraham's servant continues speaking to Rebekah's family.
"the well"

tn.ref: here I am, standing by the spring of water
tn.text: The servant interrupted what he was asking God to do by drawing God's attention to where he was standing.

tn.ref: let the young woman who comes ... the woman to whom I say ... the woman who says to me
tn.text: The servant went back to stating his request, and he had three things to say about the woman that he hoped would come.
"to get water"
This is a medium-size jar made of clay used for holding and pouring liquids. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:24:12|24:14]].
The servant finished his request.
Abraham's servant continues speaking to Rebekah's family.

To pray silently in one's mind is spoken of as if he were speaking in his heart. The word "heart" refers to his thoughts and his mind. AT: "praying" (UDB) or "praying quietly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"indeed" or "suddenly." The word "behold" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows.
This is a medium-size jar made of clay used for holding and pouring liquids. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:24:12|24:14]].

tn.text: The phrase "went down" is used because the spring was somewhere lower than where the servant was standing.
"well"
"gave water to the camels"
