tn.ref: The daughter of Bethuel, Nahor's son, whom Milcah bore to him
tn.text: "My father is Bethuel. His parents are Nahor and Milcah"
In this story, all of these items were made of gold. See how you translated these in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:24:21|24:22]].
This is a sign of humility before God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: led me by the right way
tn.text: "brought me here"
The connecting word "because" can be used to show this is why the servant worshiped God. AT: "because Yahweh led me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_connectingwords]])
This refers to Bethuel, the son of Abraham's brother Nahor.
Abraham's servant continues speaking to Rebekah's family.
"Now" (UDB). Here "Now" does not mean "at this moment," but is used to draw attention to the important point that follows.

tn.ref: if you are prepared to treat my master with family faithfulness and trustworthiness, tell me
tn.text: How they could show their faithfulness and trustworthiness can be stated explicitly. AT: "tell me if you will be faithful and trustworthy to my master by giving Rebekah to be his son's wife" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The word "you" refers to Laban and Bethuel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
These abstract nouns can be stated as "faithful and trustworthy." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This is faithfulness to family members.
The understood information can be stated clearly. AT: "But if you are not prepared to treat my master with family faithfulness and trustworthiness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: so that I may turn to the right hand, or to the left
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) deciding what to do is spoken of as if the person will physically turn one direction or another. AT: "so that I will know what do" or 2) the servant wants to know if he needs to travel somewhere else. AT: "so that I may continue on my journey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This was the father of Laban and Rebekah.

tn.ref: The thing has come from Yahweh
tn.text: "Yahweh has caused all of this to happen"

tn.ref: we cannot speak to you either bad or good
tn.text: They are saying they do not have the authority to decide whether what God has done is good or bad. AT: "we dare not judge what Yahweh is doing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The word "Look" here adds emphasis to what follows.
"Here is Rebekah"
"Laban and Bethuel's words." Here "words" stands for what they said. AT: "what Laban and Bethuel said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Bowing down before God is an expression of worship to him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: articles of silver and articles of gold
tn.text: "silver and gold items" or "things made of silver and gold"
"expensive gifts" or "valuable gifts"

tn.ref: he and the men who were with him
tn.text: "Abraham's servant and his men"
"slept there that night"
"got up the next morning"
"Let me leave and return"

tn.ref: a few more days, at least ten
tn.text: "at least ten more days"
"10" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"Then"
"Abraham's servant said"
"to Rebekah's brother and mother"
"Do not delay me" (UDB) or "Do not make me wait"
Here "way" stands for a journey. AT: "Yahweh has caused me to succeed in the purpose my journey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Allow me to leave"

tn.ref: So they sent their sister Rebekah
tn.text: "So the family sent Rebekah"
Rebekah was Laban's sister. AT: "their relative" or "Laban's sister"
This refers to the female servant who had fed Rebekah when she was a baby, cared for her when she was a child, and still served her.
Rebekah was not the sister to everyone in her family. But they called her this to show that they loved her. AT: "Our dear Rebekah"

tn.ref: may you be the mother of thousands of ten thousands
tn.text: Here "mother" stands for ancestor. AT: "may you be the ancestor of millions of people" or "may you have very many descendants"
This means a very large number or an uncountable number. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: may your descendants possess the gate of those who hate them
tn.text: Armies would break through the gate of their enemies' cities and conquer the people. AT: "may your descendants completely defeat those who hate them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Then Rebekah arose, and she and her servant girls mounted the camels
tn.text: "Then Rebekah and her servant girls went and got on the camels"

tn.ref: Thus the servant took Rebekah, and went his way
tn.text: "In this way Abraham's servant took Rebekah with him and returned to where he had come from"
This word marks a change in the story. It was telling about the servant finding a wife, and now it will tell about Isaac.
This is the name of a water well in the Negev. See how you translated it in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:16:13|16:14]].

tn.ref: Isaac went out to meditate in the field in the evening
tn.text: "One evening Isaac went out to the field to think." This must have been a long time after the servant and Rebekah left her home since they had to travel a long distance.

tn.ref: When he looked up and saw, behold, there were camels coming!
tn.text: The word "behold" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows. "When he looked up he was surprised to see camels coming"
"Rebekah looked up"

tn.ref: she jumped down from the camel
tn.text: "she quickly got off the camel"

tn.ref: So she took her veil, and covered herself
tn.text: "So she covered her face with her veil." This is a sign of respect and modesty towards the man she will marry. The full meaning of this can be made explicit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
a piece of cloth used to cover a person's head, shoulders and face

tn.ref: and took Rebekah, and she became his wife
tn.text: Both of these phrases mean that Isaac married Rebekah. AT: "and married Rebekah" or "and took her as his wife" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "So Rebekah comforted Isaac" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]].
This refers to the people named in verses 2-4.

tn.ref: Abraham gave all that he owned to Isaac
tn.text: "Isaac inherited all that Abraham owned." It was normal for the father to divide his wealth when he was old and not leave that for others to do after he died.

tn.ref: These were the days of the years of Abraham's life which he lived, 175 years
tn.text: "Abraham lived 175 years" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: Abraham breathed his last and died
tn.text: "Abraham took his last breath and died." The phrases "breathed his last" and "died" mean basically the same thing. AT: "Abraham died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This is a polite way of saying a person died. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: at a good old age, an old man with a full life
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Abraham lived a very long time. AT: "when he had lived a very long time and was very old" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: an old man with a full life
tn.text: Living a long life is spoken of as if life were a container that becomes full. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: he was gathered to his people
tn.text: This means that after Abraham died, his soul went to the same place as his relatives who died before him. This can be stated in active form. AT: "he joined his family members who had already died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the cave of Machpelah, in the field of Ephron
tn.text: Ephron owned a field in Machpelah and the cave that was in that field. Abraham bought the field from Ephron.
Machpelah was the name of an area or region. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:23:07|23:9]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are names of men. See how you translated these men's names in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:23:07|23:8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Machpela was near Mamre.

This was another name for the city of Hebron. It may have been named after Mamre, the friend of Abraham who lived there. See how you translated this place name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:23:17|23:17]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"Abraham had bought this field"
"the descendants of Heth" or "the Hittites." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:23:05|23:5]].
This can be stated in active form. AT: "They buried Abraham" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Abraham's son"
This name means "the well of the living one who sees me." See how you translated this place name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:16:13|16:14]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This word is used in English to introduce a new part of the story and information about Ishmael.
See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]].

tn.ref: These were Ishmael's sons, and these were their names, by their villages, and by their encampments; twelve princes according to their tribes
tn.text: This can be stated as two sentences. "These were the names of Ishmael's twelve sons. They led tribes that were named after them, and they each had their own villages and campsites"
"12" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
Here the word "princes" means that the men were leaders or rules of the tribes; it does not mean that they were the sons of a king.

tn.ref: These were the years of the life of Ishmael, 137 years
tn.text: "Ishmael lived 137 years" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
The terms "breathed his last" and "died" mean basically the same thing. AT: "died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

This means that after Ishmael died, his soul went to the same place as his relatives who died before him. This can be stated in active form. AT: "he joined his family members who had already died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"His descendants settled" (UDB)
"between Havilah and Shur"
Havilah was located somewhere in the Arabian Desert. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:02:11|2:11]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"in the direction of"

tn.ref: They lived in hostility with each other
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "they did not live in peace together" (UDB), or 2) "they lived away from their other relatives."

tn.ref: These were the events concerning Isaac, Abraham's son
tn.text: This sentence introduces the account of Isaac's descendants in Genesis 25:19-35:29. AT: "This is the account of the descendants of Isaac, Abraham's son" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"40 years old" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: when he took as his wife Rebekah
tn.text: "when he married Rebekah"
Bethuel was Rebekah's father. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:22:20|22:22]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This was another name for the region of Mesopotamia, which about the same location as modern Iraq. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"she was unable to become pregnant"
It can be made explicit that Rebekah was pregnant with two babies at the same time: "Rebekah, his wife, became pregnant with twins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: The children struggled together within her
tn.text: "the babies inside her kept bumping against each other" or "The babies pushed against each other within her"
Rebekah was pregnant with twins. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: She went to ask Yahweh about this
tn.text: "She went and asked Yahweh about this." It is not clear where she went. She may have gone somewhere private to pray, or she may have gone somewhere to offer a sacrifice.
"said to Rebekah"
This is poetic language. If your language has a way to indicate poetry, you could use it here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]])

tn.ref: Two nations are in your womb
tn.text: Here "two nations" stands for the two children. Each child will be the father of a nation. AT: "Two nations will come from the twins within you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: and two peoples will be separated from within you
tn.text: Here "two peoples" stands for the two children. Each child will be the father of a people. This can be translated with an active verb. AT: "and when you give birth to these two children they will be rivals" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the older will serve the younger
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "the older son will serve the younger son" or 2) "the descendants of the older son will serve the descendants of the younger son." If possible, translate it so that people could understand either meaning.
The word "behold" here adds emphasis to what follows. "indeed"

tn.ref: red all over like a hairy garment
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) his skin was red and he had a lot of hair on his body or 2) he had a lot of red hair on his body. AT: "red and hairy like a garment made of animal hair" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Translators may add a footnote that says "The name Esau sounds like the word 'hairy.'"
"holding the back part of Esau's foot"
Translators may also add a footnote that says "The name Jacob means 'he grasps the heel.'"
"60 years old" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"became good at hunting and killing animals for food"
"a peaceful man" or "a less active man"

tn.ref: who spent his time in the tents
tn.text: This speaks about time as if it were a commodity that someone could spend. AT: "who remained in the tents much of the time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This word is used to mark a change in focus, shifting from the story to background information about Isaac and Rebekah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
Here the word "loved" means "favored" or "preferred."

tn.ref: because he ate the animals that he had hunted
tn.text: "because he ate the animals that Esau had hunted" or "because he enjoyed eating the wild animal meat that Esau caught"
Since this is the beginning of a story about something that happened one time, some translators may want to start it with a phrase like "One day, Jacob cooked" in a similar manner to the UDB.
"boiled some food" or "cooked some soup." This stew was made of boiled lentils. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:gen:25:31|25:34]])
"he was weak because he was very hungry" or "he was very hungry"
"I am weak from hunger" or "I am very hungry"
Translators may add a footnote that says "The name Edom means 'red.'"
"right as firstborn to inherit most of our father's wealth" (UDB)
Esau was exaggerating to emphasize how hungry he was. AT: "I am so hungry I feel like I could die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: What good is the birthright to me?
tn.text: Esau used a question to emphasize that eating was more important than a birthright. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "My inheritance is no good to me if I die of hunger!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
What Jacob wanted Esau to swear can be stated explicitly. AT: "First swear to me that you will sell me your birthright" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
These are like beans, but their seeds are very small, round, and somewhat flat. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
"Esau showed that he did not value his birthright"
This word is used here to mark a new part of the story.
"there was a famine" or "there was another famine"

tn.ref: that had been in the days of Abraham
tn.text: The phrase "in the days" means the time when Abraham lived. AT: "that had happened during Abraham's life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Yahweh begins to speak to Isaac.
"appeared to Isaac"

tn.ref: Do not go down to Egypt
tn.text: It was common to speak of leaving the promised land as "going down" to another place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: for to you and to your descendants, I will give all these lands
tn.text: "for I will give all these lands to you and your descendants"

tn.ref: I will fulfill the oath that I swore to Abraham your father
tn.text: "I will do what I promised Abraham your father I would do"
Yahweh continues speaking to Isaac.
"I will cause you to have very many descendants."

This speaks about the number of Isaac's descendants as if they were the same as the number of stars. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:22:15|22:17]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This refers to everything we see above the earth, including the sun, moon, and stars.

tn.ref: all the nations of the earth will be blessed
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will bless all the nations of the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Abraham obeyed my voice and kept my instructions, my commandments, my statutes, and my laws
tn.text: The phrases "obeyed my voice" and "kept my instructions, my commandments, my statutes, and my laws" mean basically the same thing. AT: "Abraham obeyed me and did everything I commanded him to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Here "voice" stands for Yahweh. AT: "obeyed me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Only Isaac is mentioned because he is the leader of the family, but his whole family was with him. AT: "So Isaac and his family settled in Gerar" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "fear" refers to the unpleasant feeling a person has when there is a threat of harm to himself or others. "He was afraid to say"
"in order to take Rebekah"

tn.ref: Why did you say, 'She is my sister'?
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "Why did you say that she is your sister?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
"so he could take her"

tn.ref: What is this you have done to us?
tn.text: Abimelech used this question to scold Isaac. AT: "You should not have done this to us!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: you would have brought guilt upon us
tn.text: This speaks about causing someone to be guilty as if "guilt" were an object that is placed on someone. AT: "you would have caused us to be guilty of taking a man's wife" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "us" refers to Abimelech and his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: will surely be put to death
tn.text: Abimelech may have intended to tell someone to kill anyone who might harm Isaac or Rebekah. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will put him to death" or "I will order my men to kill him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

"in Gerar"
This means "one hundred times as much as he planted." It can be translated more generally as "a very large crop" (UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"Isaac became rich" or "He became rich"

tn.ref: in the days of Abraham his father
tn.text: The phrase "in the days of" stands for a person's lifetime. AT: "when Abraham, his father, was living" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Possible meanings are 1) this is another action to force Isaac and his people to leave. AT: "Then Abimelech said" or "Finally Abimelech said" or 2) Abimelech made this decision because he saw that his people were jealous and acting in a hostile way towards Isaac. AT: "Therefore Abimelech said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_connectingwords]])
"much stronger than we are"
Only Isaac is mentioned because he is the leader, but his family and servants went with him. AT: "So Isaac and his household left" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

"which Abraham's servants had dug"

tn.text: The phrase "in the days of" stands for a person's lifetime. AT: "when Abraham, his father, was living." See how this was translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:26:15|26:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: The Philistines had stopped them up
tn.text: This was the reason that Isaac dug them out. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_events]])
"had filled them with earth"

"men who tended the herds"

"Then Isaac's servants dug" (UDB)
"the herdsmen of Gerar argued with Isaac's herdsmen"
"so Isaac gave it"

Translators may add a footnote that says "The name Rehoboth means 'make room for' or 'empty place.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Isaac was speaking about himself and his household.

tn.ref: Isaac went up from there to Beersheba
tn.text: Here "went up" is probably a reference to going north. Say that he departed in the most natural way for your language. AT: "Isaac left there and went to Beersheba"
"will cause your descendants to increase greatly" or "will cause your descendants to be very many"
"for my servant Abraham" or you can make the full meaning explicit. AT: "because I promised my servant Abraham that I would do this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
You can make explicit why Isaac built an altar. AT: "Isaac built an altar there to sacrifice to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: called on the name of Yahweh
tn.text: To "call on" means to pray or to worship. Here "name" stands for Yahweh. AT: "prayed to Yahweh" or "worshiped Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"went to Isaac"
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Possible meanings are 1) "Abimelech's friend" or 2) "Abimelech's advisor."
This is the name of a man. See how you translated his name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:21:22|21:22]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This refers to Abimelech, Ahuzzath, and Phicol. One of them spoke and the other two agreed with what he said. It does not mean they all spoke at the same time. AT: "one of them said"
"We know" or "We are certain"

tn.ref: Isaac made a feast for them, and they ate and drank
tn.text: Eating a meal together was a part of making a covenant with one another. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "them" refers to "Abimelech, Ahuzzath, and Phicol"
Here "they" refers to Isaac, Abimelech, Ahuzzath, and Phicol. AT: "they all ate" (UDB)
"They awoke early"
"So he called the well Shibah." Translators may add a footnote that says "The name Shibah sounds like the word that means 'oath.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Translators may add a footnote saying "Beersheba can mean either "well of the oath" or "well of seven." (See note on [[:en:bible:notes:gen:21:31|21:32]])
Most of Genesis 26 was about Isaac. These verses are about his older son Esau.
"40" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

These are names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"the descendant of Heth" or "a descendant of Heth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.text: Here "they" refers to Judith and Basemath. To make someone sorrowful or miserable is spoken of as if "sorrow" were an object that a person could bring to another person. AT: "They made Isaac and Rebekah sorrowful" or "Isaac and Rebekah were miserable because of them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This speaks about being nearly blind as if the eyes were a lamp and the light has nearly gone out. AT: "he was nearly blind" or "he was almost blind" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"And Esau replied"

This refers to physical death.

"your hunting equipment"

"hunt a wild animal for me"

tn.ref: Make delicious food for me, the sort that I love
tn.text: The word "delicious" refers to something that tastes very good. AT: "Cook for me the tasty meat that I love" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.text: Esau and Jacob were both sons of Isaac and Rebekah. They are called "his son" and "her son" to emphasize that one parent preferred one son over the other son.

"Bring me a wild animal that you hunt and kill"
"cook for me the tasty meat that I love." See how this was translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:27:03|27:04]].

tn.text: Rebekah said "my voice" to refer to what she was saying. AT: "obey me and do what I tell you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.text: The word "delicious" refers to something that tastes very good. See how a similar sentence was translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:27:03|27:4]].

tn.text: "Then take it to your father"

"before he dies"
"I am a man with smooth skin" or "I am not hairy"

tn.text: "and he will think that I am a liar" or "he will know that I am deceiving him"

tn.text: Being cursed or blessed is spoken of as if a curse and a blessing are objects that are placed on a person. AT: "Then because of this, he will curse me and not bless me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: My son, let any curse fall on me
tn.text: "let your curse be on me, my son." Being cursed is spoken of as if the curse were on object that is placed on the person. AT: "let your father curse me instead of you, my son" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Rebekah said "my voice" to refer to what she was saying. AT: "obey what I tell you" or "obey me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"bring me the young goats"

tn.ref: made delicious food, just like his father loved
tn.text: The word "delicious" refers to something that tastes very good. See how a similar sentence was translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:27:03|27:4]].

tn.text: Here the word "hand" refers to power. The two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second clarifies that the brother whom Jacob intended was Esau. AT: "from the power of my brother, Esau" or "from my brother, Esau" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: I am afraid of him, that he will
tn.text: "I am afraid that he will"

tn.ref: But you said, 'I will certainly make you prosper. I will make your descendants ... number.'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated an an indirect quotation. AT: "But you said that you would certainly prosper me, and that you would make my descendants ... number" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
"do good to you" or "treat you well"

tn.ref: I will make your descendants like the sand of the sea
tn.text: This speaks about the very large number of Jacob's descendants as if their number will be like the grains of sand on the seashore. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: which cannot be numbered for their number
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "which no one can count because of their number" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"200" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"20 ... 30 ... 40 ... 10" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"and their young"

tn.ref: These he gave these into the hand of his servants, every herd by itself
tn.text: Here "into the hand" means to give control over them. AT: "He divided them into small herds, and gave each of his servants control over one herd" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: put a space between each of the herds
tn.text: "let each herd travel at a distance from the other herds"
"He commanded"

tn.ref: asks you ... animals in front of you?'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "asks you who your master is, where you are going, and who owns these animals" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
"Who is your master?"

tn.ref: whose are these animals in front of you?
tn.text: "who owns these animals in front of you?"

tn.ref: Then you will say, 'They are your servant Jacob's. They are a gift sent to my master Esau. And see, he is also coming after us.'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "Then I want you to tell him that all of these things belong to Jacob, his servant, and he his giving them to his master, Esau. And tell him that Jacob is on the way to meet him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
Jacob is referring to himself in a polite way as Esau's servant.
Jacob is referring to Esau is a polite way as his master.
Here "us" refers to the servant speaking and the other servants bringing herds to Esau. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: gave instructions to the second group
tn.text: "commanded the second group"

tn.ref: You must also say, 'Your servant Jacob
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "You will say also, 'Your servant Jacob'" or 2) "You will say, 'Also, Your servant Jacob.'"
"I will calm him down" or "I will make his anger go away"
"he will welcome me kindly"

tn.ref: So the gifts went on ahead of him
tn.text: Here "gifts" stands for the servants taking the gifts. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "himself" emphasizes that Jacob did not go with the servants. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])
"his two servant wives." This means Zilpah and Bilhah.
a shallow place in a river that is easy to cross
This is the name of a river. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"all that he had"
"until dawn" (UDB)
"thigh socket." This is the place where the upper leg bone connects to the hip.

tn.ref: Jacob's hip was dislocated as he wrestled with him
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The man injured Jacob's hip as he wrestled with him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"the sun will rise soon"
Here "bless" means to pronounce a formal blessing on someone and to cause good things to happen to that person.

tn.ref: I will not let you go unless you bless me
tn.text: This can be stated in positive form. AT: "Absolutely not! You must bless me first, then I will let you go" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
Translators may add a footnote that says "The name Israel means 'He struggles with God.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Here "men" means "people" in general.

tn.ref: He said, "Why is it that you ask my name?"
tn.text: "He said, 'Why would you ask about my name?'" This rhetorical question was meant to shock, rebuke and cause Jacob to ponder over what just happened between him and the other man he just wrestled with. AT: "Do not ask me for my name!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Translators may add a footnote that says: "The name Peniel means 'the face of God.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Being "face to face" means that two people are seeing each other in person, at a close distance.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "yet he spared my life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: That is why to this day
tn.text: This marks a change from the story to background information about the descendants of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
This means to the day that the author was writing this.
This refers to the muscle that connects the thigh bone to the thigh socket.
"thigh socket"
"while striking"
The word "behold" here alerts us to pay attention to a surprising new part of the story.
"400 men" (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: Jacob divided the children ... female servants
tn.text: This does not mean Jacob divided the children evenly so that each woman had the same amount of children with her. Jacob divided the children so that each one went with his or her mother. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"servant wives." This refers to Bilhah and Zilpah.

tn.ref: He himself went on ahead of them
tn.text: Here "himself" emphasizes that Jacob went alone in front of the others. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])
Here the word "bow" means to bend over to humbly express respect and honor toward someone. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
"meet Jacob"

tn.ref: embraced him, hugged his neck, and kissed him
tn.text: This can be translated as a new sentence. AT: "Esau put his arms around Jacob, hugged him, and kissed him"
This can be translated more explicitly. AT: "Then Esau and Jacob cried because they were happy to see each other again" (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: he saw the women and the children
tn.text: "he saw the women and children who were with Jacob"

tn.ref: The children whom God has graciously given your servant
tn.text: The phrase "your servant" is a polite way for Jacob to refer to himself. AT: "These are the children God has kindly given me, your servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
"servant wives." This refers to Bilhah and Zilpah.
This is a sign of humility and respect before another person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: What do you mean by all these groups that I met?
tn.text: The phrase "all these groups" refers to the groups of servants that Jacob sent to give gifts to Esau. AT: "Why did you send all of those different groups to meet me?"

tn.ref: To find favor in the sight of my master
tn.text: Here "sight" stands for a person's thoughts or opinion. AT: "So that you, my master, would be pleased with me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The phrase "my master" is a polite way of referring to Esau. (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
The word "animals" or "property" is understood. AT: "I have enough animals" (UDB) or "I have enough property" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: if I have found favor in your sight
tn.text: Here "sight" stands for a person's thoughts or opinions. AT: "if you are pleased with me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "hand" refers to Jacob. AT: "this gift that I am giving to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This can be translated as a new sentence: "my hand. For certainly"

tn.ref: I have seen your face, and it is like seeing the face of God
tn.text: The meaning of this simile is unclear. Possible meanings are 1) Jacob is happy that Esau has forgiven him like God has forgiven him or 2) Jacob is amazed to see his brother again like he was amazed to see God or 3) Jacob is humbled to be in Esau's presence like he was humbled to be in God's presence. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

Here "face" stands for Esau. It may be best to translate as "face" because of the importance of the word "face" here with "face of God" and "face to face" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:32:29|32:30]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "that my servants brought to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: God has dealt graciously with me
tn.text: "God has treated me very well" or "God has blessed me very much"

tn.ref: Thus Jacob urged him, and Esau accepted it
tn.text: It was customary to refuse a gift first, but then to accept the gift before the giver was offended.
This is a polite and formal way of referring to Esau. AT: "You, my master, know" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
The meaning can be stated more explicitly. AT: "the children are too young to travel fast" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: If they are driven hard even one day
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "If we force them to go too fast even for one day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Please let my master go on ahead of his servant
tn.text: This is a polite and formal way of Jacob referring to himself. AT: "My lord, I am your servant. Please go ahead of me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: at the pace of the livestock that are before me
tn.text: "at the speed the animals I am looking after can go"
This is a mountainous area in the region of Edom. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:32:03|32:3]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Jacob uses a question to emphasize that Esau does not need to leave men. AT: "Do not do that!" or "You do not need to do that!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This is a polite and formal way of referring to Esau. AT: "You, my master, have" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]]).
Translators may also add a footnote that says, "The name Succoth means 'shelters.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
It is implied that the house is also for his family. AT: "built a house for himself and his family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"for the animals he looked after"
This starts a new part of the story. The author describes what Jacob did after he rested in Succoth.

tn.ref: When Jacob came from Paddan Aram
tn.text: "After Jacob left Paddan Aram"

tn.ref: When Jacob ... he arrived ... He camped
tn.text: This only mentions Jacob because he is the leader of the family. It is implied that his family was with him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"He set up his camp near"
"piece of land"
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Shechem is the name of a city and the name of a man.
"100" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
Translators may add a footnote that says: "The name El Elohe Israel means 'God, the God of Israel.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Here this word is used to mark a new part of the story.
This is the name of Leah's daughter. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:30:19|30:21]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a people group. See how you translated the similar word "Hivites" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:10:15|10:17]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is referring to Hamor not Shechem. Also, "prince" here does not mean son of a king. It means Hamor was the leader of the people in that area.

tn.ref: assaulted her, and slept with her
tn.text: Shechem raped Dinah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

"He was very attracted to her" (UDB). This speaks about Shechem loving Dinah and wanting to be with her as if something were forcing him to come to Dinah. This can be stated in active form. AT: "He wanted very much to be with Dinah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This means he spoke affectionately to convince her that he loved her and that he wanted her to love him also.
"Now" is used here to mark a change from the story to background information about Jacob. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
The word "he" refers to Shechem.
This means that Shechem had greatly dishonored and disgraced Dinah by forcing her to sleep with him.
This is a way of saying that Jacob did not say or do anything about the matter. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"Hamor ... went to meet Jacob"
"The men were outraged"

tn.ref: They were very angry ... should not have been done
tn.text: This can be stated as a direct quotation spoken by Jacob's son, as in the UDB. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

Here the word "Israel" refers to every member of Jacob's family. Israel as a people group was disgraced. AT: "he had humiliated the family of Israel" or "he had brought shame on the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"assaulting Jacob's daughter"

tn.ref: for such a thing should not have been done
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "for he should not have done such a terrible thing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Hamor spoke with Jacob and his sons"
Here the word "love" refers to romantic love between a man and a woman. AT: "loves her and wants to marry her"

tn.ref: give her to him as a wife
tn.text: In some cultures, the parents decide whom their children will marry.
To intermarry is to marry a member of a different racial, social, religious or tribal group. AT: "Allow marriages between your people and ours"

tn.ref: the land will be open to you
tn.text: "the land will be available to you"
"Shechem said to Dinah's father Jacob"

tn.ref: Let me find favor in your eyes, and whatever you tell me I will give
tn.text: Here "eyes" stands for a person's thoughts or opinion. AT: "If you will approve of me, then I will give you whatever you ask" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
In some cultures, it is customary for a man to give money, property, cattle, and other gifts to the bride's family at the time of marriage.

tn.ref: The sons of Jacob answered Shechem and Hamor his father with deceit
tn.text: The abstract noun "deceit" can be stated as the verb "lied." AT: "But the sons of Jacob lied to Shechem and Hamor when they answered them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This means that Shechem had greatly dishonored and disgraced Dinah by forcing her to sleep with him. See how you translated "defiled" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:34:04|34:5]].
"Jacob's sons said to Shechem and Hamor"

tn.ref: We cannot do this thing, to give our sister
tn.text: "We cannot agree to give Dinah in marriage"

tn.ref: for that would be a disgrace to us
tn.text: "for that would cause us shame." Here "us" refers to Jacob's sons and all the people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: give our daughters to you ...  take your daughters to ourselves
tn.text: This means they will allow a person from Jacob's family to marry a person who lives in Hamor's land.

tn.ref: Their words pleased Hamor and his son Shechem
tn.text: Here "words" stands for what was said. AT: "Hamor and his son Shechem agreed with what Jacob's sons said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"to become circumcised"
"Jacob's daughter Dinah"

tn.ref: because he was the most honored person in all his father's household
tn.text: This can be translated as a new sentence. It can be made explicit that Shechem knew the other men would agree to be circumcised because they greatly respected him. AT: "Shechem knew all the men in his father's household would agree with him because he was the most honored among them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It was common for leaders to meet at the city gate to make official decisions.
"Jacob, his sons, and the people of Israel"
Here "us" includes Hamor, his son and all the people they spoke with at the city gate. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: let them live in the land and trade in it
tn.text: "let them live and trade in the land"

tn.ref: for, really, the land is large enough for them
tn.text: Shechem uses the word "really" to add emphasis to his statement. "because, certainly, the land is large enough for them" or "because, indeed, there is plenty of land for them"

tn.ref: take their daughters ... give them our daughters
tn.text: This refers to marriages between the women of one group and the men of the other group. See how you translated similar phrases in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:34:08|34:9]].
Hamor and Shechem his son continue to talk to the city elders.

tn.ref: Only on this condition will the men agree to live with us and become one people: if every male among us is circumcised, as they are circumcised
tn.text: "Only if every man among us is circumcised, as the men of Israel are circumcised, will they agree to live among us and unite with us as one people"

tn.ref: Will not their livestock and their property—all their animals be ours?
tn.text: Shechem uses a question to emphasize that Jacob's livestock and property will belong to the people of Shechem. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "All of their animals and property will be ours." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "So Hamor and Shechem had someone circumcise all the men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"third" is the ordinal number for three. It can be stated without the ordinal number. AT: "After two days" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])

tn.ref: when they were still in pain
tn.text: "when the men of the city were still in pain"
"took their swords"
Here "city" stands for the people. AT: "they attacked the people of the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: security, and they killed all the males
tn.text: This can be translated as a new sentence. "security. Simeon and Levi killed all the men of the city"

tn.ref: with the edge of the sword
tn.text: Here "edge" stands for the blade of the sword. AT: "with the blade of their swords" or "with their swords" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"the dead bodies of Hamor, Shechem, and their men"
"stole everything in the city that was valuable"

tn.ref: because the people had defiled their sister
tn.text: Shechem alone had defiled Dinah, but Jacob's sons considered Shechem's entire family and everyone in the city responsible for this act.
This means that Shechem had greatly dishonored and disgraced Dinah by forcing her to sleep with him. See how you translated "defiled" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:34:04|34:5]].
"Jacob's sons took the people's flocks"
"all their possessions and money"

tn.ref: All their children and their wives, they captured
tn.text: "They captured all their children and wives"

Causing someone to experience trouble is spoken of as if trouble were an object that is brought and placed on a person. AT: "caused great problems for me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: to make me stink to the inhabitants of the land
tn.text: Causing the people in the surrounding areas to hate Jacob is spoken of as if Jacob's sons made him smell bad physically. This can be translated as a new sentence. AT: "You have made me repulsive to the people who live in the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I am few in number ... against me and attack me, then I will be destroyed, I and my household
tn.text: Here the words "I" and "me" refer to all of Jacob's household. Jacob only says "I" or "me" since he is the leader. AT: "My household is small ... against us and attack us, then they will destroy all of us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: gather themselves together against me and attack me
tn.text: "form an army and attack me" or "form an army and attack us"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "they will destroy me" or "they will destroy us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Should Shechem have dealt with our sister as with a prostitute?
tn.text: Simeon and Levi use a question to emphasize that Shechem did what was wrong and deserved to die. AT: "Shechem should not have treated our sister as if she were a prostitute!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The phrase "go up" is used because Bethel is higher in elevation than Shechem.

tn.ref: Build an altar there to God
tn.text: God speaks about himself in the third person. AT: "Build an altar there to me, your God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
"said to his family"

tn.ref: Put away the foreign gods that are among you
tn.text: "Throw away your idols" or "Get rid of your false gods"

tn.ref: purify yourselves, and change your clothes
tn.text: This was the custom of cleansing oneself morally and physically before going to worship God.
Putting on a new clothes was a sign that they had made themselves clean before approaching God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: in the day of my distress
tn.text: Possible meanings for "day" are 1) the day when Jacob fled from Esau or 2) "day" stands for a period of time when Jacob was distressed. AT: "when I was in a difficult situation" or "when I was in trouble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"so everyone in Jacob's household gave" or "so all of his family and servants gave"
Here "in their hand" stands for what they own. AT: "that were in their possession" or "that they had" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the rings that were in their ears
tn.text: "their earrings" (UDB). Possible meanings are 1) the gold in the earrings could have been used to make more idols or 2) they took these earrings from the city of Shechem after they attacked it and killed all the people. The earrings would have reminded them of their sin.

tn.ref: God made panic to fall on the cities
tn.text: God causing the people of the cities to be afraid of Jacob and his family is spoken of as if panic were an object that fell on the cities. The abstract noun "panic" can be stated as "afraid." AT: "God made the people in the surrounding cities afraid of Jacob and those with him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here "cities" stands for the people who live in the cities. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

It is implied that no one attacked anyone in Jacob's family. But two of the sons, Simeon and Levi had attacked the Canaanites relatives of Shechem after he seized and slept with Jacob's daughter. Jacob was afraid they would seek revenge in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:34:30|34:30]]. AT: "Jacob's family" or "Jacob's household" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This is the name of a city. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:28:18|28:19]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Translators may add a footnote that says: "The name El Bethel means 'God of Bethel.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: there God had revealed himself to him
tn.text: "there God made himself known to Jacob"
This is the name of a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
A nurse is a woman who takes care of another woman's child. The nurse was highly honored and important to the family.

tn.ref: She was buried down from Bethel
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "They buried her down from Bethel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The phrase "down from" is used because they buried her in a place that was lower in elevation than Bethel.
Translators may add a footnote that says: "The name Allon Bacuth means 'Oak tree where there is weeping.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: When Jacob came from Paddan Aram
tn.text: It can be made explicit that they were in Bethel. AT: "After Jacob left Paddan Aram, and while he was in Bethel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "bless" means to pronounce a formal blessing on someone and to cause good things to happen to that person.

tn.ref: but your name will no longer be called Jacob
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "but your name will no longer be Jacob" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"God said to Jacob"

God told Jacob to produce children so that there would be many of them. The word "multiply" explains how he was to be "fruitful." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:01:22|1:22]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: A nation and a company of nations will come from you
tn.text: Here "nation" and "nations" refer to Jacob's descendants who will establish these nations. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "went up" is used because where God dwells is typically thought of as being up or above the world. AT: "God left him"
This is a memorial pillar which was simply a large stone or boulder set up on its end.

tn.ref: He poured out a drink offering over it and poured oil on it
tn.text: This is a sign that he is dedicating the pillar to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
Translators may also add a footnote that says "The name Bethel means 'house of God.'"
This is another name for the town of Bethlehem.

tn.ref: carry grain for the famine of your houses
tn.text: Here "houses" stands for families. AT: "carry grain home to help your family during this famine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: so your words will be verified
tn.text: Here "words" stands for what was said. This can be stated in active form. AT: "so I may know what you say is true" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This implies that Joseph would have his soldiers execute the brothers if he finds out they are spies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: in that we saw the distress of his soul
tn.text: The word "soul" stands for Joseph. AT: "because we saw how distressed Joseph was" or "because we saw that Joseph was suffering" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Therefore this distress has come upon us
tn.text: The abstract noun "distress" can be stated as the verb "suffering." AT: "That is why we are suffering like this now" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: Did I not tell you, 'Do not sin against the boy,' but you would not listen?
tn.text: Reuben uses a question to scold his brothers. AT: "I told you not to hurt the boy, but you would not listen!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Did I not tell you, 'Do not sin against the boy'
tn.text: This has a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "Did I not tell you not to sin against the boy" or "I told you not to harm the boy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
Here "Now" does not mean "at this moment," but both "Now" and "see" are used to draw attention to the important point that follows.

tn.ref: his blood is required of us
tn.text: Here "blood" stands for Joseph's death. His brothers thought Joseph was dead. The phrase "is required of us" means they must be punished for what they did. AT: "we are getting what we deserve for his death" or "we are suffering for having killed him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: They did not know ... an interpreter between them
tn.text: This shifts from the main storyline to background information that explains why the brothers thought Joseph could not understand them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

An "interpreter" is someone who translates what one person says into another language. Joseph placed an interpreter between himself and his brothers to make it seem like he did not speak their language.

tn.ref: He turned from them and wept
tn.text: It is implied that Joseph wept because he was emotional after hearing what his brothers said. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Joseph was still speaking a different language and using the interpreter to speak to his brothers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "eyes" refers to their sight. AT: "bound him in their sight" or "bound him as they watched" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"to give them the supplies they needed"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "The servants did for them everything that Joseph commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: As one of them opened his sack to give his donkey feed in the lodging place, he saw his money. Behold, it was in the opening of his sack
tn.text: "When they stopped at a place for the night, one of the brothers opened his sack to get food for his donkey. In the sack he saw his money!"
The word "behold" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows.

tn.ref: My money has been put back
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Someone has put my money back" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Look in my sack!"

To become afraid is spoken of as if their heart were sinking. Here "hearts" stands for courage. AT: "And they became very afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]]
"the lord of Egypt"
"spoke harshly"
Spies are people who secretly try to get information about a country to help another country. See how you translated "spies" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:42:09|42:9]].

tn.ref: We said to him, 'We are honest men. We are not spies. We are twelve brothers, sons of our father. One is no longer alive ... land of Canaan.'
tn.text: This has a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "We told him that we are honest men and not spies. We said that we are twelve brothers, sons of our father, and that one brother is no longer alive ... land of Canaan" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
The word "brother" is understood. AT: "One brother is no longer alive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: the youngest is this day with our father
tn.text: The word "brother" is understood. AT: "the youngest brother is with our father right now" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"The lord of Egypt"

tn.ref: take grain for the famine in your houses
tn.text: Here "houses" stands for "family." AT: "take grain to help your family during the famine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"go home" or "leave"

tn.ref: and you will trade in the land
tn.text: "and I will allow you to buy and sell in this land"
This phrase is used here to mark an important event in the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.
"to their surprise." The word "behold" here shows that the brothers were surprised by what they saw.

tn.ref: You have bereaved me of my children
tn.text: "you have deprived me of my children" or "you have caused me to lose two of my children"

tn.ref: All these things are against me
tn.text: "all these things hurt me"
This is a request for Reuben to take Joseph with him and to care for him on the journey. AT: "Put me in charge of him" or "Let me take care of him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: My son will not go down with you
tn.text: It was common to use the phrase "go down" when speaking of traveling from Canaan to Egypt. AT: "My son, Benjamin, will not go with you to Egypt"
Here "you" is plural and refers to Jacob's older sons. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: For his brother is dead and he alone is left
tn.text: The full meaning can be made explicit. AT: "For my wife, Rachel, only had two children. Joseph is dead and Benjamin is the only one left" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: on the road in which you go
tn.text: "while you a traveling to Egypt and back" or "while you are away." Here "road" stands for traveling.

tn.ref: then you will bring down my gray hair with sorrow to Sheol
tn.text: To "bring down ... to Sheol" is way of saying they will cause him to die and go to Sheol. He uses the word "down" because it was commonly believed sheol is somewhere underground. AT: "then you will cause me, an old man, to die of sorrow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This stands for Jacob and emphasizes his old age. AT: "me, an old man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: The famine was severe in the land
tn.text: The word "Canaan" is understood. This information can be made explicit. AT: "The famine was severe in the land of Canaan" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

This phrase is used here to mark the beginning of a new part of the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
"when Jacob and his family had eaten"
"Jacob's older sons had brought"
Here "us" refers to Jacob, his sons, and the rest of the family. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
"Judah told his father Jacob"
This refers to Joseph, but the brothers did not know it was Joseph. They referred to him as "the man" or "the man, the lord of the land" as in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:42:29|42:30]].

tn.ref: warned us, 'You will not see my face unless your brother is with you.'
tn.text: This has a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "warned us that we would not see his face unless we brought our youngest brother with us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
"was very serious when he warned us, saying"

tn.ref: You will not see my face
tn.text: Judah uses this phrase twice in 43:3-5 to emphasize to his father that they cannot return to Egypt without Benjamin. The phrase "my face" refers to the man, who is Joseph. AT: "You will not see me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Judah is referring to Benjamin, Rachel's last born before she died.
It was common to use the phrase "go down" when speaking of traveling from Canaan to Egypt.

tn.ref: Why did you treat me so badly
tn.text: "Why did you cause me so much trouble"
"The man asked many questions"
Here "us" is exclusive and refers to the brothers who went to Egypt and spoke with "the man." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: He said, 'Is your father still alive? Do you have another brother?'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "He asked us directly if our father was still alive and if we had another brother." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: We answered him according to these questions
tn.text: "We answered the questions he asked us"

tn.ref: How could we have known that he would say ... down?
tn.text: The sons use a question emphasize that the did not know what the man would tell them to do. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "We did not know he would say ... down!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: he would say, 'Bring your brother down'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "he would tell us to bring our brother down to Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
It was common to use the word "down" when speaking of traveling from Canaan to Egypt.

tn.ref: We will rise and go that we may live and not die, both we, you, and also our children
tn.text: The phrases "we may live" and "not die" mean the same thing. Judah is emphasizing that they have to buy food in Egypt in order to survive. AT: "We will go now to Egypt and get grain so our whole family will live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Here "We" refers to the brothers who will travel to Egypt. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
Here "we" refers to the brothers, Israel, and the whole family. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
Here "we" refers to the brothers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
Here "you" is singular and refers to Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Here "our" refers to the brothers. This refers to the small children who were most likely to die during a famine. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: I will be a guarantee for him
tn.text: The abstract noun "guarantee" can be stated as the verb "promise." AT: "I will promise to bring him back" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
How Jacob will hold Judah responsible can be stated clearly. AT: "You will make me answer to you about what happens to Benjamin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This speaks about "blame" as if it were an object that a person has to carry. AT: "you may blame me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: For if we had not delayed
tn.text: Judah is describing something that could have happened in the past but did not. Judah is scolding his father for waiting so long to send his sons to Egypt to get more food. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: we would have come back here a second time
tn.text: "we would have returned twice"

tn.ref: If it be so, now do this
tn.text: "If this is our only choice, then do it"
It was common to use the word "down" when speaking of traveling from Canaan to Egypt.
an oily substance with a sweet smell used for healing and protecting skin. AT: "medicine." See how you translated these words in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:37:25|37:25]].
"seasonings." See how you translated these words in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:37:25|37:25]].
a small, green tree nut (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
a tree nut with a sweet flavor (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

tn.ref: Take double money in your hand
tn.text: Here "hand" stands for the whole person. AT: "Take double the money with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: The money that was returned in the opening of your sacks, carry again in your hand
tn.text: Here "hand" stands for the whole person. The phrase "that was returned" can be stated in active form. AT: "take back to Egypt the money someone put in your sacks" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Take also Benjamin"
"return"

tn.ref: May God Almighty give you mercy before the man
tn.text: The abstract noun "mercy" can be stated as the adjective "kind." AT: "May God Almighty cause the man to be kind to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"Simeon"

tn.ref: If I am bereaved of my children, I am bereaved
tn.text: "If I lose my children, then I lose my children." This means that Jacob knows he must accept whatever happens to his sons.
Here "hand" refers to the entire person. AT: "they took" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
It was common to use the phrase "went down" when speaking of traveling from Canaan to Egypt.
"Benjamin with Joseph's older brothers"
The "steward" was responsible for managing Joseph's household activities.
Here "brought" can be translated as "took." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])
"into Joseph's house"
"Joseph's brothers were afraid"

tn.ref: they were brought to Joseph's house
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "they were going into Joseph's house" or "the steward was taking them into Joseph's house" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: It is because of the money that was returned in our sacks the first time we were brought in
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The steward is bringing us into the house because of the money that someone put back in our sacks" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: that he may seek an opportunity against us. He might arrest us
tn.text: This can be translated as a new sentence. AT: "He is waiting for the opportunity to accuse us, so that he might arrest us"
It is common to use the phrase "came down" when speaking of traveling from Canaan to Egypt.
The brothers continue speaking to the steward of the house.
This phrase is used here to mark an important event in the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.

tn.ref: when we reached the lodging place
tn.text: "when we came to the place that we were going to stay for the night"
The word "behold" here shows that the brothers were surprised by what they saw.

tn.ref: every man's money was in the opening of his sack, our money in full weight
tn.text: "each one of us found the full amount of his money in his sack"

tn.ref: We have brought it back in our hands
tn.text: Here "hands" stands for the whole person. AT: "We have brought the money back with us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Other money we have also brought down in our hand to buy food
tn.text: Here "hand" stands for the whole person. AT: "We have also brought more money to buy food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
It common to use the word "down" when speaking of traveling from Canaan to Egypt.
The abstract noun "Peace" can be stated as a verb. AT: "Relax" (UDB) or "Calm yourselves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: Your God and the God of your father
tn.text: The stewards is not speaking about two different Gods. AT: "Your God, the God your father worships" (UDB)
This custom helped tired travelers to refresh themselves after walking long distances. The full meaning of this statement may be made explicit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Feed" is dry food that is set aside for animals

tn.ref: they brought the gifts which were in their hand
tn.text: Here "hand" stands for the entire person. AT: "the brothers brought the gifts they had with them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This is a way of showing honor and respect. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
They refer to their father as "Your servant" to show respect. AT: "Our father who serves you"
These words basically mean the same thing. They laid down in front of the man to show him respect. AT: "They bowed down in front of him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
This means "he looked up." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: his mother's son, and he said
tn.text: This can be translated with a new sentence. AT: "his mother's son. Joseph said"

tn.ref: Is this your youngest brother ... me?
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) Joseph is truly asking a question to confirm that this man is Benjamin, or 2) it is a rhetorical question. AT: "So this is your youngest brother ... me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This is a friendly way one man speaks to another man of lower rank. AT: "young man" (UDB)

tn.ref: hurried to go out of the room
tn.text: "hurried out of the room"

tn.ref: for he was deeply moved about his brother
tn.text: The phrase "deeply moved" refers to having a strong feeling or emotion when something important happens. AT: "for he had strong feelings of compassion for his brother" or "for he had strong feelings of affection for his brother" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
It can be made explicit to whom Joseph is speaking. AT: "and said to his servants" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This means to distribute the food so that people may eat.

tn.ref: The servants served Joseph by himself and the brothers by themselves. The Egyptians there ate with him by themselves
tn.text: This means that Joseph, the brothers, and the other Egyptians are eating in three different places within the same room. AT: "The servants served Joseph by himself and the brothers by themselves and the Egyptians, who were eating with him, by themselves"

tn.ref: The Egyptians there ate with him by themselves
tn.text: These are probably other Egyptian officials who ate with Joseph, but they still sat separately from him and the Hebrew brothers.

tn.ref: because the Egyptians could not eat bread with the Hebrews, for that is detestable to the Egyptians
tn.text: This can be translated as a new sentence: "They did this because the Egyptians thought it was shameful to eat with the Hebrews"
Here "bread" stands for food in general. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

It is implied that Joseph had arranged where each brother would sit. You can make clear the implied information. AT: "The brothers sat across from the man, according to how he arranged their places" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: the firstborn according to his birthright, and the youngest according to his youth
tn.text: The "firstborn" and the "youngest" are used together to mean all the brothers were sitting in order according to their age. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
"The men were very surprised when they realized this"

tn.ref: But Benjamin's portion was five times as much as any of his brothers
tn.text: The phrase "five times" can be stated more generally. AT: "But Benjamin received a portion that was much bigger than what his brothers received"
This begins a new event in the story. Most likely this is the next morning after the feast.
The "steward" was responsible for managing Joseph's household activities.
Their money was silver coins most likely in a small bag.
"in his sack"

tn.ref: Put my cup, the silver cup
tn.text: "Put my silver cup"

tn.ref: in the sack's opening of the youngest
tn.text: The word "brother" is understood. AT: "in the youngest brother's sack" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"The morning light shown"

tn.ref: the men were sent away, they and their donkeys
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "they sent the men away, along with their donkeys" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Why have you returned evil for good?
tn.text: This question is used to scold the brothers. AT: "You have treated us badly, after we were good to you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Is this not the cup from which my master drinks, and the cup that he uses for divination?
tn.text: This question is used to scold the brothers. AT: "You already know that this is the cup that my master uses for drinking and for fortune telling!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: You have done evil, this thing that you have done
tn.text: This repeats "you have done" for emphasis. AT: "What you have done is very evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Here "words" stands for what was said. AT: "spoke what Joseph told him to say"

tn.ref: Why does my master speak such words as these?
tn.text: Here "words" stands for what was said. The brothers refer to the steward as "my master." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with greater authority. It can be stated in the second person. AT: "Why are you saying this, my master?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: Far be it from your servants that they would do such a thing
tn.text: The brothers refer to themselves as "your servants" and "they." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with greater authority. AT: "We would never do such a thing!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: Far be it from your servants
tn.text: Something that a person would never do is spoken of as if it were an object that person wants to put very far from himself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This adds emphasis to what the brothers say next.

tn.ref: the money that we found in our sacks' openings
tn.text: "you know the money that we found in our sacks"

tn.ref: we brought again to you out of the land of Canaan
tn.text: "we brought back to you from Canaan"

tn.ref: How then could we steal out of your master's house silver or gold?
tn.text: The brothers use a question to emphasize that they would not steal from the lord of Egypt. AT: "So we would never take anything from your master's house!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
These words are used together to mean that they would not steal anything of any value.

tn.ref: With whomever of your servants it is found
tn.text: The brothers refer to themselves as "your servants." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with greater authority. It can be stated in the first person. Also, "is is found" can be stated in active form. AT: "If you find that one of us has stolen the cup" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: we also will be my master's slaves
tn.text: The phrase "my master" refers to the steward. This can be stated in the second person. AT: "you may take us as your slaves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: Now also let it be according to your words
tn.text: Here "now" does not mean "at this moment," but is used to draw attention to the important point that follows. Also, "words" stands for what was said. AT: "Very well. I will do what you said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: He with whom the cup is found will be my slave
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "If I find the cup in one of your sacks, that person will be my slave" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"lowered his sack"
The word "brother" is understood. AT: "the oldest brother ... the youngest brother" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: youngest, and the cup was found in Benjamin's sack
tn.text: This can be translated as a new sentence and in active form. AT: "youngest. The steward found the cup in Benjamin's sack" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The word "they" refers to the brothers. Tearing clothes was a sign of great distress and sorrow. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
"and they returned"
"Joseph was still there"
"they fell before him." This is a sign of the brothers wanting the lord to be merciful to them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: Do you not know that a man like me practices divination?
tn.text: Joseph uses a question to scold his brothers. AT: "Surely you know that a man like me can learn things by magic!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: What can we say to my master? What can we speak? Or how can we justify ourselves?
tn.text: All 3 questions mean basically the same thing. They use these questions to emphasize that there is nothing they can say to explain what happened. AT: "We have nothing to say, my master. We cannot speak anything of value. We cannot justify ourselves." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: What can we say to my master ... my master's slaves
tn.text: Here "my master" refers to Joseph. This is a formal way of speaking to someone with greater authority. It can be stated in second person. AT: "What can we say to you ... your slaves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: God has found out the iniquity of your servants
tn.text: Here "found out" does not mean God just found out what the brothers did. It means God is now punishing them for what they did. AT: "God is punishing us for our past sins"

The brothers refer to themselves as "your servants." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with greater authority. It can be stated in first person. AT: "our iniquity" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: and he also in whose hand the cup was found
tn.text: Here "hand" stands for the whole person. Also, "was found" can be stated in active form. AT: "and the one who had your cup" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Far be it from me that I should do so
tn.text: Something that a person would never do is spoken of as if it were an object the person wants put far away from him. AT: "It is not like me to do something like that" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The man in whose hand the cup was found
tn.text: Here "hand" stands for the whole person. Also, "was found" can be stated in active form. AT: "The man who had my cup" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"approached"
