Judah refers to himself as "your servant." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with more authority. This can be stated in first person. AT: "let me, your servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: speak a word in my master's ears
tn.text: Here "word" is a metonym that stands for what is said. And "ear" is a synecdoche that stands for the whole person. AT: "speak to you, my master" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "my master" refers to Joseph. This is a formal way of speaking to someone with more authority. This can be stated in second person. AT: "to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: do let your anger burn against your servant
tn.text: Being angry is spoke of as if it were a burning fire. AT: "please do not be angry with me, your servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: for you are just like Pharaoh
tn.text: Judah compares the master to Pharaoh to emphasize the great power that the master has. He is also implying that he does want the master to become angry and execute him. AT: "for you are as powerful as Pharaoh and could have your soldiers kill me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: My master asked his servants, saying, 'Do you have a father or a brother?'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "My master asked us if we have a father or a brother." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

Judah refers to Joseph with the words "my master" and "his." He also refers to himself and his brothers as "his servants." AT: "You, my master, asked us, your servants" or "You asked us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
Judah continues to speak before Joseph

tn.ref: And we said to my master, 'We have a father ... his father loves him.'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "And we said to my master that we have a father ... his father loves him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
Judah refers to Joseph as "my master." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with greater authority. AT: "we said to you, my master" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
This refers to love for a friend or family member.

tn.ref: And you said to your servants, 'Bring him down to me that I may see him.'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "And you said to your servants that we should bring our youngest brother to you so that you may see him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: And you said to your servants
tn.text: Judah refers to himself and his brothers as "your servants." AT: "Then you said to us, your servants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
It was common to use the word "down" when speaking of traveling from Canaan to Egypt. AT: "Bring him to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: And we said to my master, 'The boy cannot ... father would die.'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "And we said to my master that the boy cannot ... father would die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
It is implied that their father would die from sorrow. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Judah continues his story to Joseph

tn.ref: And you said to your servants, 'Unless your youngest brother comes down with you, you will not see my face again'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "And you said to your servants that unless our youngest brother comes with us, we would not see you again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: And you said to your servants
tn.text: Judah refers to himself and his brothers as "your servants." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with greater authority. AT: "Then you said to us, your servants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
It was common to use the word "down" when speaking of traveling from Canaan to Egypt.

tn.ref: you will not see my face again
tn.text: Here "face" stands for the whole person. AT: "you will not see me again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

This phrase is used here to mark the beginning of a new part of the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])

tn.ref: we went up to your servant my father
tn.text: It was common to use the phrase "went up" when speaking of traveling from Egypt to Canaan.

tn.ref: we told him the words of my master
tn.text: Judah refers to Joseph as "my master." Also, "words" stands for what was said. AT: "we told him what you said, my master" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: And our father said, 'Go again, buy us some food'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "And our father told us to go again to Egypt to buy food for us and our families" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: And we said, 'We cannot go down. If our youngest brother ... is with us.'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "And we said to him that we cannot go down to Egypt. We told him that if our youngest brother is with us ... is with us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
Here "face" stands for the whole person. AT: "to see the man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Judah continues his story to Joseph

tn.ref: said to us, 'You know that my wife bore me two sons. And the one went out from me and I said, "Surely he is torn in pieces, and I have not seen him since." And if you take this one also from me and harm comes to him, you will bring down my gray hair with sorrow to Sheol'
tn.text: This has a two level and three level quotation. They can be stated as indirect quotations. AT: "said to us that we know that his wife, Rachel, bore him only two sons, and that one of them went out and an animal tore him to pieces, and he has not seen him since. Then he said that if we take his other son and something bad happens to him, then we would cause him to die of sorrow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
Here "us" does not include Joseph. (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
Here "You" is plural and refers to the brothers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "a wild animal has torn him to pieces" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Something bad happening to a person is spoken of as if "harm" were something that travels and comes to a person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you will bring down my gray hair with sorrow to Sheol
tn.text: To "bring down ... to Sheol" is way of saying they will cause him to die and go to Sheol. He uses the word "down" because it was commonly believed Sheol is somewhere underground. AT: "then you will cause me, an old man, to die of sorrow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This stands for Jacob and emphasizes his old age. AT: "me, an old man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This does not mean "at this moment," but is used to draw attention to the important point that follows.

tn.ref: therefore, when I come ... sorrow to Sheol
tn.text: Judah is describing to Joseph a realistic but hypothetical case of what he will expect will happen to Jacob when he returns without Benjamin. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: when I come to your servant
tn.text: Here "come" can be translated as "go" or "return."

tn.ref: the lad is not with us
tn.text: "the boy is not with us"

tn.ref: since his life is bound up in the boy's life
tn.text: The father saying he would die if his son died is spoken of as if their two lives were physically bound together. AT: "since he said he would die if the boy did not come back" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Judah is speaking about a hypothetical case in the future as if it would certainly happen. (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: And your servants will bring down the gray hair of your servant our father with sorrow to Sheol
tn.text: To "bring down ... to Sheol" is way of saying they will cause him to die and go to Sheol. He uses the word "down" because it was commonly believed Sheol is somewhere underground. AT: "And we will have caused our old father to die of sorrow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Judah refers to himself and his brothers as "your servants." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with greater authority. AT: "And we, your servants" or "And we" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: the gray hair of your servant our father
tn.text: Here "gray hair" stands for Jacob and emphasizes his old age. AT: "our old father" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: For your servant became a guarantee for the boy to my father
tn.text: The abstract noun "guarantee" can be stated with the verb "promised." AT: "For I promised my father concerning the boy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Judah refers to himself as "your servant." AT: "For I, your servant" or "For I" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: then I will bear the guilt to my father
tn.text: Being considered guilty is spoken of as if "guilt" were something that a person carries. AT: "then my father may blame me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This does not mean "at this moment," but is used to draw attention to the important point that follows.
Judah refers to himself as "your servant." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with greater authority. AT: "let me, your servant" or "let me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
Judah refers to Joseph as "my master." AT: "to you, my master" or "to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
It was going to use the phrase "go up" when speaking about traveling from Egypt to Canaan.

tn.ref: For how can I go up to my father if the boy is not with me?
tn.text: Judah uses a question to emphasize the grief he would have if Benjamin did not return home. AT: "I cannot return to my father if the boy is not with me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: I am afraid to see the evil that would come on my father
tn.text: A person suffering terribly is spoken of as if "evil" were a thing that comes upon a person. AT: "I am afraid to see how much my father would suffer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This means he could not control his emotions. It can be stated in positive form. AT: "was about to start crying"
"near him"
Here "house" stands for the people in the Pharaoh's palace. AT: "everyone in Pharaoh's palace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"terrified of him"
The meaning can be stated more explicitly. AT: "whom you sold as a slave to the trader who brought me to Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"do not be upset" or "do not be distressed"
The meaning can be stated more explicitly. AT: "that you sold me as a slave and sent me here to Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "life" stands for the people that Joseph saved from dying during the famine. AT: "so I could save many lives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: there are still five years in which there will be neither plowing nor harvest
tn.text: "there will be five more years without planting or harvesting." Here "neither plowing nor harvest" stands for the fact that the crops still will not grow because of the famine. AT: "and the famine will last five more years" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: to preserve you as a remnant in the earth
tn.text: "so that you and your families would not completely perish from the earth" or "to make sure your descendants would survive" (UDB)

tn.ref: to keep you alive by a great deliverance
tn.text: The abstract noun "deliverance" can be stated as "rescuing." AT: "to keep you alive by rescuing you in a mighty way" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: he has made me a father to Pharaoh
tn.text: Joseph advising and helping Pharaoh is spoken of as if Joseph were Pharaoh's father. AT: "he has made me a guide to Pharaoh" or "he has made me the chief adviser to Pharaoh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "house" stands for the people who live in his palace. AT: "of all his household" or "of all his palace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: ruler of all the land of Egypt
tn.text: Here "land" stands for the people. AT: "ruler over all the people of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here Joseph means that he is ruler in second place to Pharaoh, the king of Egypt. This understood information can be made clear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It was common to use the phrase "go up" when speaking about going from Egypt to Canaan. AT: "go back to my father"

tn.ref: say to him, 'This is what your son Joseph says, "God has ... all that you have
tn.text: This is a quotation with three layers. It can be simplified to two layers. AT: "tell him that this is what I said: 'God has ... all that you have" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
It was common to use the phrase "come down" when speaking about going from Canaan to Egypt. AT: "Come here to me"
This speaks about "poverty" as if it were a destination. AT: "waste away" or "starve" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: your eyes see, and the eyes of my brother Benjamin
tn.text: The word "eyes" stands for the entire person. AT: "All of you and Benjamin can see" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: that it is my mouth that speaks to you
tn.text: The word "mouth" stands for the entire person. AT: "that I, Joseph, am speaking to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: about all my honor in Egypt
tn.text: "how the people in Egypt greatly honor me"
It was common to use the word "down" when speaking of traveling from Canaan to Egypt. AT: "my father here to me"

tn.ref: He hugged his brother Benjamin's neck and wept, and Benjamin wept on his neck
tn.text: "Joseph hugged his brother Benjamin, and they both wept"
In ancient Near East, it is common to greet a relative with a kiss. If your language has an affectionate greeting for a relative, use that. If not, use what is appropriate.
This means Joseph was crying while he kissed them.

tn.ref: After that his brothers talked with him
tn.text: Earlier they were too afraid to speak. Now they feel they can speak freely. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "After that his brothers talked freely with him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: The news of the matter was told in Pharaoh's house: "Joseph's brothers have come"
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. It may also be stated in active form. AT: "Everyone in Pharaoh's palace heard that Joseph's brothers had come" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This stands for Pharaoh's palace.

tn.ref: Say to your brothers, 'Do this: load your animals and go to the land of Canaan. Get your father and your households and come to me. I will give you the good of the land of Egypt, and you will eat the fat of the land.'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "Tell your brothers to load their animals and go to Canaan to get their father and families. Tell them to come here, and I will give them the best land in Egypt and the best food we have to offer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: I will give you the good of the land of Egypt
tn.text: "I will give you the best land in Egypt"

tn.ref: you will eat the fat of the land
tn.text: The best food that a land produces is spoken of as if it were the fat portion of the land. AT: "you will eat the best food in the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Pharaoh continues to tell Joseph what to tell his brothers.
This does not mean "at this moment," but is used to draw attention to the important point that follows.

tn.ref: you are commanded, 'Do this, take carts out of the land of Egypt for your children and for your wives. Get your father and come. Do not be concerned about your possessions, for the good of all the land of Egypt is yours'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "also tell them to take carts out of the land of Egypt for their children and wives, and to get their father and come here. They should not worry about bringing their possessions, for I will give them the best things we have in Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "I also command you to tell them" or "also tell them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Carts" are wagons with two or four wheels. Animals pull the carts.

tn.ref: and gave them provisions for the journey
tn.text: "and gave them what they needed for traveling"

tn.ref: he gave each man changes of clothing
tn.text: Each man received a set of clothes except for Benjamin who received 5 sets of clothes. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"300 pieces" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: ten donkeys ... and ten female donkeys
tn.text: The donkeys were included as part of the gift. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Possible meanings include 1) "do not argue" and 2) "do not become afraid"
It was common to use the word "up" when speaking of traveling from Egypt to Canaan.

tn.ref: he is ruler over all the land of Egypt
tn.text: Here "land of Egypt" stands for the people of Egypt. AT: "he rules all the people of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "heart" stands for the whole person. AT: "and he was astonished" or "he was very surprised" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"he did not accept that what they said was true"
"They told Jacob"

tn.ref: all the words of Joseph that he had said to them
tn.text: Here "words" stands for what was said. AT: "everything that Joseph had said to them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the spirit of Jacob their father revived
tn.text: The word "spirit" stands for the whole person. AT: "Jacob their father recovered" or "Jacob their father became very excited" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"came to Beersheba"
"Yes, I am listening"
It was common to use the phrase "go down" when speaking of traveling from Canaan to Egypt.

tn.ref: I will make you a great nation
tn.text: Here "you" is singular and refers to Jacob. This "you" also stands for Israel's descendants that will become a large nation. AT: "I will give you many descendants, and they will become a great nation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"to Egypt"

tn.ref: I will surely bring you up again
tn.text: The promise was made to Jacob, but the promise would be fulfilled to all of Israel's descendants. AT: "I will surely bring your descendants out of Egypt again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
It was common to use the word "up" when speaking about traveling from Egypt to Canaan.

tn.ref: And Joseph will close your eyes with his own hand
tn.text: The phrase "close you eyes with his own hand" is a way of saying that Joseph will be present when Israel dies and it will be Joseph who will close Jacob's eyelids at the time of his death. AT: "And Joseph will even be present with you at the time of your death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
It was a custom to pull down the eyelids when a person died with their eyes open. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"set out from"
"Carts" are wagons with two or four wheels. Animals pull the carts. See how you translated "carts" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:45:19|45:19]].
"they had acquired" (UDB) or "they had gained"
"Jacob brought with him"
"his grandsons"
"his granddaughters"
This refers to the names of the people that the author is about to list.
"of Israel's family members"

tn.ref: Hanoch and Pallu and Hezron and Carmi ... Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul ... Gershon, Kohath, and Merari
tn.text: These are all names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These were the sons of Judah by his wife, Shua. See how you translated these names in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:38:03|38:3-5]].
These were the sons of Judah by his daughter-in-law, Tamar. See how you translated these names in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:38:29|38:29-30]].

tn.ref: Hezron ... Hamul ... Tola, Puvah, Lob ... Shimron ... Sered, Elon ... Jahleel
tn.text: These are all names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of Leah's daughter. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:30:19|30:21]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: His sons and his daughters numbered thirty-three
tn.text: three** - Here "sons" and "daughters" refer to Jacob's sons, daughters, and grandchildren related to Leah. AT: "Altogether he had 33 sons, daughters, and grandchildren" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: Ziphion ... Haggi, Shuni ... Ezbon, Er, Arodi ... Areli ... Imnah ... Ishvah, Ishvi ... Beriah ... Heber ... Malchiel
tn.text: These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of Leah's female servant. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:29:23|29:24]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: These sons she bore to Jacob—sixteen in all
tn.text: This refers to 16 children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren that were related to Zilpah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"Asenath" is the name of the woman whom Pharaoh gave to Joseph as his wife. See how you translated this is [[:en:bible:notes:gen:41:44|41:45]].  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"Potiphera" is the father of Asenath. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:41:44|41:45]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

On is a city, also called Heliopolis, which was "the City of the Sun" and the center of worship of the sun god Ra. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:41:44|41:45]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Bela, Becher, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim, and Ard
tn.text: These are names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This refers to the 14 sons and grandsons related to Rachel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of Rachel's female servant. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:29:28|29:29]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This refers to the 7 children and grandchildren related to Bilhah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
six** - "66" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"70" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: to show the way before him to Goshen
tn.text: "to show them the way to Goshen"

tn.ref: Joseph prepared his chariot and went up
tn.text: Here "Joseph" stands for his servants. AT: "Joseph's servants prepared his chariot and Joseph went up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The phrase "went up" is used because Joseph is traveling to a higher elevation to meet his father. AT: "went to meet Israel"

tn.ref: hugged his neck, and wept on his neck a long time
tn.text: "put his arms around his father, and wept for a long time"
"Now I am ready to die" or "Now I will die happy"

tn.ref: since I have seen your face, that you are still alive
tn.text: Here "face" stands for the entire person. Jacob was expressing joy at seeing Joseph. AT: "since I have seen you alive again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "house" stands for his family. AT: "his father's family" or "his father's household" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I will go up and tell Pharaoh
tn.text: It was common to use the phrase "go up" when referring to someone going to speak with someone with greater authority. AT: "I will go tell Pharaoh"

tn.ref: tell Pharaoh, saying, 'My brothers ... all that they have.'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "tell Pharaoh that my brothers ... all that they have" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
This phrase is used here to mark an important event that is about to happen in the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.

tn.ref: and asks, 'What is your occupation?' that you should say
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "and asks you about what kind of work you do, you should say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: you should say, 'Your servants have ... both we, and our forefathers.'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "you should say that you have ... both you and your forefathers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

Joseph's family are to refer to themselves as "your servants" when they speak to Pharaoh. This is a formal way of speaking to someone with greater authority. It can be stated in the first person. AT: "We, your servants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: every shepherd is an abomination to the Egyptians
tn.text: The abstract noun "abomination" can be translated with the adjective "disgusting." AT: "Egyptians think shepherds are disgusting" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: He took five of his brothers
tn.text: The UDB reorders the event with Pharaoh chronologically, whereas the ULB lists the events as the author wrote it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_events]])
"Your servants shepherd flocks"

Joseph's brothers refer to themselves as "your servants." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with more authority. This can be stated in first person. AT: "We, your servants" or "We" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
"both we and our forefathers" or "both we and our ancestors"

tn.ref: We come as temporary residents in the land
tn.text: "We have come to stay for a while in Egypt"
"There is no grass to eat"
This does not mean "at this moment," but is used to draw attention to the important point that follows.

tn.ref: The land of Egypt is before you
tn.text: "The land of Egypt is open to you" or "All of the land of Egypt is available to you"

tn.ref: Settle your father and your brothers in the best region, the land of Goshen
tn.text: "Settle your father and your brothers in the land of Goshen, which is the best region"

tn.ref: If you know any capable men among them
tn.text: It is implied that they are capable of taking care of animals. AT: "If you know of any men among them who have great skill taking care of animals" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "blessed" means to express a desire for positive and beneficial things to happen to that person.
"How old are you?"

tn.ref: The years of my travels are a hundred and thirty
tn.text: The phrase "years of my travels" refers to how long he has lived on the earth traveling from one place to another. AT: "I have traveled on the earth for 130 years" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: The years of my life have been few ... not been as long as those of my ancestors
tn.text: Jacob means his life is short compared to the lives of Abraham and Isaac.
Jacob has experienced much pain and trouble during his life.

tn.ref: Then Joseph settled his father and his brothers
tn.text: "Then Joseph took care of his father and his brothers and helped them establish where they would live"
This is another name for the land of Goshen. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: according the number of their dependents
tn.text: Here, the word "dependents" means the small children in the family. AT: "according to how many small children were in their families"
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here the author starts to tell a new part of the story.

tn.ref: The land of Egypt and the land of Canaan
tn.text: This refers to the people living in these lands. AT: "The people of Egypt and the people of Canaan" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"became thin and weak"

tn.ref: Joseph gathered all the money that was in the land of Egypt and in the land of Canaan, by selling grain to the inhabitants
tn.text: "The people of Egypt and Canaan spent all of their money buying grain from Joseph"
Most likely Joseph ordered his servants to gather and bring the money. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: When all the money of the lands of Egypt and Canaan was spent
tn.text: Here "lands" stands for the people who live in the lands. This can be stated in active form. AT: "When the people of Egypt and Canaan used up all their money" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: of the lands of Egypt and Canaan
tn.text: "from the land of Egypt and from the land of Canaan"

tn.ref: Why should we die in your presence because our money is gone?
tn.text: The people used a question to emphasize how desperate they are to buy food. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "Please, do not let us die because we have used up all of our money!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here "bread" stands for food in general. AT: "He gave them food" (UDB) or "He provided them with food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"the people came to Joseph"

tn.ref: We will not hide from my master
tn.text: The people refer to Joseph as "my master." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with greater authority. It can be stated in second person. AT: "We will not hide from you, our master" or "We will not hide from you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: There is nothing left in the sight of my master
tn.text: Here "sight" stands for Joseph himself. AT: "We have nothing left to give you, our master" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Why should we die before your eyes, both we and our land?
tn.text: The word "eyes" refers to Joseph's sight. The people use a question to emphasize how desperate they are to buy food. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "Please do not just watch as we die and our land is ruined!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Why should we die ... both we and our land
tn.text: The land becomes useless and ruined because there is no seed to plant; thus it is spoken of as if the land would die. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: In this way, the land became Pharaoh's
tn.text: "So the land became Pharaoh's"

tn.ref: It was only the land of the priests that Joseph did not buy
tn.text: "But he did not buy the land of the priests"

tn.ref: the priests were given an allowance
tn.text: An "allowance" is an amount of money or food that someone regularly gives to another person. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Pharaoh gave the priests a certain amount of food each day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: They ate from the allotment which Pharaoh gave them
tn.text: "They ate from what Pharaoh gave them"
"that you might sow"

tn.ref: At the harvest, you must give a fifth to Pharaoh, and four parts will be your own
tn.text: The word "fifth" is a fraction. AT: "At harvest time you will divide the crops into five parts. You will give one part back to Pharaoh for payment and the four parts are for your own" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_fraction]])

tn.ref: for food for your households and your children
tn.text: You can state clearly the understood information. AT: "for food for your households and for food for your children" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: May we find favor in your eyes
tn.text: Here "eyes" stands for thoughts or opinions. AT: "May you be pleased with us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This means that someone is approved of by someone else. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"over the land of Egypt" or "throughout the land of Egypt"
This means to the time that the author was writing this.
fifth** - Translate this the same way you did "a fifth" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:47:23|47:24]].

tn.ref: They were fruitful and multiplied greatly
tn.text: The word "multiplied" explains how they were "fruitful." AT: "They had very many children" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Here "fruitful" means to prosper or to have children. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"17 years" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: so the years of Jacob's life were one hundred forty-seven years
tn.text: seven years** - "so Jacob lived to be 147 years old" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: When the time approached for Israel to die
tn.text: This speaks about time as if it travels and comes to a place. AT: "When it was almost time for Israel to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: If now I have found favor in your sight
tn.text: Here "sight" stands for thoughts or opinions. AT: "If I have found favor with you" or "If I have pleased you" (UDB)
This does not mean "at this moment," but is used to draw attention to the important point that follows.
This means that someone is approved of by someone else. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: put your hand under my thigh
tn.text: This act is a sign of making a serious promise. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:24:01|24:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
The abstract nouns "faithfulness" and "trustworthiness" can be translated as adjectives. AT: "treat me in a faithful and trustworthy manner" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: Please do not bury me in Egypt
tn.text: The word "please" adds emphasis to this request.

tn.ref: When I sleep with my fathers
tn.text: Here "sleep" is a polite way to refer to dying. AT: "When I die and join my family members who died before me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
"Promise me" or "Make an oath to me"
"promised him" or "made an oath to him"
This phrase is used here to mark the beginning of a new part of the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
"someone said to Joseph"
"Listen, your father." Here the word "look" is used to get Joseph's attention.
"So Joseph took"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "When someone told Jacob" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: your son Joseph has arrived to see you
tn.text: "your son Joseph has come to you"

tn.ref: Israel gathered strength and sat up in bed
tn.text: Here the author speaks of Israel struggling to to sit up in bed as if he were gathering "strength" as someone gathers actual things. AT: "Israel made a great effort to sit up in bed" or "Israel struggled as he sat up in bed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is the name of a city. See how you translated the name of this city in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:28:18|28:19]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: in the land of Canaan. He blessed me and said to me
tn.text: This can be translated with the new sentence starting in a different place. AT: "in the land of Canaan, and he blessed me. And he said to me"
This refers to God pronouncing a formal blessing on someone.

tn.ref: and said to me, 'Behold, I will make you fruitful, and multiply you. I will make of you an assembly of nations. I will give this land to your descendants as an everlasting possession.'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "and said to me that he would make me fruitful and multiply me. And, he said that he would make me an assembly of nations and he would give this land to my descendants as an everlasting possession." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
God used the word "behold" here to alert Jacob to pay attention to what he was about to tell him.

tn.ref: I will make you fruitful, and multiply you
tn.text: The phrase "multiply you" explains how God would make Jacob "fruitful." AT: "I will give you very many descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: I will make of you an assembly of nations
tn.text: Here "you" refers to Jacob, but it stands for Jacob's descendants. AT: "I will make your descendants into many nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"a permanent possession"
This does not mean "at this moment," but is used to draw attention to the important point that follows.

tn.ref: Ephraim and Manasseh will be mine
tn.text: Ephraim and Manasseh each will receive a portion of land just like Joseph's brothers.

tn.ref: they will be listed under the names of their brothers in their inheritance
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1)the rest of Joseph's children would inherit land as part of the tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh or 2) Joseph will be given separate land from Ephraim and Manasseh and Joseph's other children will inherit that land. AT: "as for their inheritance, you will list them under the names of their brothers"
This is another name for the town of Bethlehem. See how you translated the name of this city in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:35:16|35:16]].
The author is giving background information. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"Whose sons are these?"
A father would often pronounce a formal blessing on his children or grandchildren.

tn.ref: Now Israel's eyes ... could not see
tn.text: The word "Now" is used here to mark a change from the story to background information about Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"Israel kissed them"
Here "face" stands for the whole person. AT: "to see you again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

When Joseph placed his sons on Israel's lap or knees it was a sign that Israel was adopting them. This gave the children special inheritance rights from Jacob. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: then he bowed with his face to the earth
tn.text: Joseph bowed down to show honor to his father. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: Manasseh in his left hand toward Israel's right hand
tn.text: Joseph places the boys so that Israel will put his right hand on Manasseh. Manasseh was the oldest brother and the right hand was the sign he would receive the greater blessing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: his right hand and laid it upon Ephraim's head
tn.text: Placing the right hand on Ephraim's head was the sign that he would receive the greater blessing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
Here "Joseph" also stands for Ephraim and Manasseh. Since Joseph is the father, he is the only one mentioned here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: The God before whom my fathers Abraham and Isaac walked
tn.text: Serving God is spoken of as if it were walking before God. AT: "The God who my grandfather Abraham and father Isaac served" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
God has taken care of Israel like a shepherd takes care of his sheep. AT: "who has cared for me like a shepherd cares for his animals" (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Possible meanings are 1) this refers to the angel that God sent to protect Jacob or 2) this refers to God who appeared in angel form to protect Jacob.
"delivered me"

tn.ref: May my name be named in them, and the name of my fathers Abraham and Isaac
tn.text: Here "name" stands for the person. The phrase "my name be named in them" is an idiom that means a person is remembered because of another person. This can be stated in active form. AT: "May people remember Abraham, Isaac, and me because of Ephraim and Manasseh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: May they grow into a multitude on the earth
tn.text: Here "they" refers to Ephraim and Manasseh, but it stands for their descendants. AT: "May they have many descendants who will live all over the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Put your right hand upon his head
tn.text: The right hand was the sign of the greater blessing which the oldest son was supposed to receive. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: He also will become a people, and he also will be great
tn.text: Here "He" refers to Manasseh, but it stands for his descendants. AT: "Your older son will have many descendants, and they will become a great people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "words" stand for what is said. AT: "that day, saying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: The people of Israel will pronounce blessings by your names saying
tn.text: "The people of Israel will speak your names when they are blessing others"

tn.ref: by your names saying, 'May God make you like Ephraim and like Manasseh'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "by your names. They will ask God to make others like Ephraim and like Manasseh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
Israel saying Ephraim's name first is another way he indicates that Ephraim will be greater than Manasseh.
Giving Ephraim the greater blessing and making him more important than Manasseh is spoken of as if Israel physically put Ephraim in front of Manasseh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: will be with you ... bring you back ... your fathers
tn.text: Here "you" and "your" are plural and refer to all the people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
This is an idiom that means God will help and bless the people of Israel. AT: "God will help you" or "God will bless you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "bring" can be translated as "take." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])
"land of your ancestors"

tn.ref: To you, as one who is above your brothers, I give to you the mountain slope
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) Joseph having more honor and authority than his brothers is spoken of as if he were physically above them or 2) Jacob means he is giving more land to Joseph than he is giving to Joseph's brothers. AT: 1) "To you, who is greater than your brothers, I give the mountain slope" or 2) "To you, I give one more ridge than I give your brothers. I give to you the mountain slope" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "you" is singular and refers to Joseph. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: the mountain slope that I took from the Amorites with my sword and my bow
tn.text: Here "sword" and "bow" stands for fighting in battle. AT: "the portion of land I fought for and took from the Amorites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This begins Jacob's final blessings to his sons. This continues through [[:en:bible:notes:gen:49:27|49:27]]. Jacob's blessings are written in poetic form. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]])

tn.ref: Assemble yourselves and listen, you sons of Jacob. Listen to Israel, your father
tn.text: Both sentences say the same thing for emphasis. AT: "Come and listen carefully to your father" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: you sons of Jacob. Listen to Israel, your father
tn.text: Jacob is referring to himself in the third person. It can be stated in the first person. AT: "my sons. Listen to me, your father" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: my firstborn, my might, and the beginning of my strength
tn.text: The phrases "my firstborn, my might" and "the beginning of my strength" mean the same thing. The words "might" and "strength" stand for Jacob's ability to produce children. The words "firstborn" and "beginning" mean that Reuben is his first child. AT: "my first child after I became a man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: outstanding in dignity, and outstanding in power
tn.text: This can be stated as a new sentence. AT: "You are first in honor and power" or "You surpass everyone else in honor and power"
Jacob compares Reuben to water in a strong current to emphasize that he cannot control his anger and he is not stable. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: you will not have the preeminence
tn.text: "you shall not be first among your brothers"

tn.ref: because you went up to your father's bed. Then you defiled it; you went up to my couch
tn.text: Here "bed" and "couch" stand for Jacob's concubine, Bilhah. Jacob is referring to when Reuben slept with Bilhah (See: [[:en:bible:notes:gen:35:21|35:22]]). AT: "because you went to my bed and slept with Bilhah my concubine. You have shamed me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: you went up to your father's bed ... you went up to my couch
tn.text: Both statements mean the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This does not just mean they are brothers by birth. Jacob is emphasizing that they worked together to kill the people of Shechem.

tn.ref: Weapons of violence are their swords
tn.text: "They use their swords to hurt and to kill people"

Jacob uses the words "soul" and "heart" to refer to himself and is saying that other people,and perhaps God also, honor him so much that he does not wish to join with those who make plans to do evil. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: do not come into their council; do not join in their meetings
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Jacob combines them to emphasize that he does not want to participate in their wicked plans. AT: "I certainly will not join with them to make any plans" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This refers to Simeon and Levi crippling oxen just for fun.
This refers to cutting the sinews of an animal's leg so that it cannot walk.

tn.ref: May their anger be cursed, for it was fierce—and their fury, for it was cruel
tn.text: God cursing Simeon and Levi is spoken of as if God were cursing their anger and fury. This can be stated in active form. AT: "The Lord says, 'I will curse them because of their fierce anger and their cruel fury" or "I, the Lord, will curse them because of their fierce anger and their cruel fury" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
In prophecy, the prophet will often speak the words of God as if God himself were speaking. This emphasizes how closely united the prophet and God are.

tn.ref: and their fury, for it was cruel
tn.text: The words "I will curse" are understood. AT: "and I will curse their fury, for it was cruel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: I will divide them in Jacob and scatter them in Israel
tn.text: The word "I" refers to God. The word "them" refers to Simeon and Levi but they are a metonymy standing for their descendants. The words "Jacob" and "Israel" are a metonymy standing for all people of Israel. AT: "I will divide their descendants and scatter them among all the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: your brothers will praise you ... Your father's sons will bow down before you
tn.text: These two statements mean the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

The second sentence states the reason for the first sentence. The word "for" or "because" can be added to make this clear. AT: "will praise you. For your hand" or "will praise you because your hand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_connectingwords]])

tn.ref: Your hand will be on the neck of your enemies
tn.text: This is a way of saying "You will conquer your enemies." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means to bend over to humbly express respect and honor toward someone. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
Jacob speaks about Judah as if he were a lion's cub. Jacob is emphasizing Judah's strength. AT: "Judah is like a young lion" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: My son, you have gone up from your victims
tn.text: "You, my son, have come back from eating your prey"
Jacob also compares Judah to a female lion. The lioness is the primary hunter and protector of her cubs. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Who would dare to awaken him?
tn.text: Jacob uses a question to emphasize how terrifying Judah is to other people. AT: "No one wants to wake him up." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: The scepter will not depart from Judah, nor the ruler's staff from between his feet
tn.text: The "scepter" and the "staff" are long decorated sticks that kings carried. Here they are metonymies that stand for the power to rule. And, "Judah" stands for his descendants. AT: "The power to rule will always be with the descendants of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: until Shiloh comes. The nations will obey him
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "Shiloh" means "tribute." AT: "until the nations obey him and bring him tribute" or 2) "Shiloh" refers to the city of Shiloh. AT: "until the ruler comes to Shiloh. Then the nations will obey him." Many people consider this a prophecy about the Messiah who is a descendant of King David. David is a descendant of Judah.
Here "nations" refer to the people. AT: "The people of the nations will obey him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Binding his donkey ... to the choice vine
tn.text: Both statements mean the same thing. It is implied that the vines are so full of grapes that the master does not mind that his donkey eats some of them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Possible meanings for all occurrences of "his" or "he" are 1) they refer to Judah's descendants. AT: "their ... they" or 2) they  refer to the ruler in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:49:10|49:10]], which may refer to the Messiah.

tn.ref: he has washed ... in the blood of grapes
tn.text: Both statements mean the same thing. It implies that there are so many grapes that they can wash their clothes in the juice. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Often in prophecy events that will happen in the future are described as something that has already happened in the past. This emphasizes that this event will certainly happen. AT: "they will wash" or "he will wash" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pastforfuture]])
This speaks about the grape juice as if it were blood. This emphasizes how red the juice is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: His eyes will be as dark as wine
tn.text: This refers to the color of a person's eyes to the red color of wine. Possible meanings are 1) dark eyes imply healthy eyes or 2) people eyes will be red from drinking too much of wine. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: his teeth as white as milk
tn.text: This compare the color of the person's teeth to the white color of milk. This implies that there will be so many healthy cows they will have much milk to drink. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to the descendants of Zebulun. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "He" stands for sea towns that the people of Zebulun will inhabit or build. These cities will provide shelter for ships. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
a part of the sea that is next to land and is a safe place for ships

Jacob speaks about Issachar and his descendants as if they are a donkey. This emphasizes that they will work very hard. AT: "The descendants of Issachar will be like a strong donkey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Often in prophecy events that will happen in the future are described as something that is already happening. This emphasizes that the event will certainly happen. It can be stated in the future tense. AT: "Issachar will be" or "The descendants of Issachar will be"
Here "Issachar" is a metonymy that stands for his descendants. AT: "The descendants of Issachar ... They see ... They will" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Possible meanings are 1) "lying down between the packs they were carrying" or 2) "lying down between two sheep pens." Either way, Jacob speaks about Issachar's descendants as if they are donkeys that have worked hard and are lying down to rest. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: a good resting place and the pleasant land
tn.text: "a resting place that is good and that the land is pleasant"

tn.ref: He will bend his shoulder to the burden
tn.text: The phrase "bend his shoulder to the burden" is a way of saying "work very hard to carry the load" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: become a servant for the task
tn.text: "will work for others as slaves"
Here "Dan" stands for his descendants. AT: "The descendants of Dan will judge their people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Possible meanings for "his people" are 1) "the people of Dan" or 2) "the people of Israel"

tn.ref: Dan will be a snake beside the road
tn.text: Jacob speaks about Dan and his descendants as if they were snakes. Though a snake is small, it can bring down a rider off his horse. So Dan, though a small tribe, is very dangerous to its enemies. AT: "The descendants of Dan will be like a snake beside the road" (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I wait for your salvation, Yahweh
tn.text: The abstract noun "salvation" can be translated as "save." AT: "I wait for you, Yahweh, to save me"
The word "I" refers to Jacob.
These refer to the descendants of each man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "heels" stands for the raiders who are running away from the descendants of Gad. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "rich" is a way of saying "delicious." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Naphtali is a doe let loose
tn.text: Jacob speaks about the descendants of Naphtali as if they were a female deer that is free to run. This may emphasize that they will be swift messengers. AT: "The descendants of Naphtali will be like deer set free" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
A "fawn" is a baby deer. The meaning of the Hebrew word is unclear. Some versions translate it as "have beautiful words" or "speak beautiful things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here "Joseph" is a metonymy that stands for his descendants. Jacob speaks about them as if they were a tree branch that produces a lot of fruit. This emphasizes that they will greatly increase in number. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
a main branch of a tree

tn.ref: whose branches climb over the wall
tn.text: Branches that grow and extend over a wall are spoken of as if they were climbing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Jacob continues to bless Joseph and his descendants.

The person holding the bow steady is spoken of as if the bow itself will remain steady. It is implied he is holding it steady as he aims at his enemy. AT: "he will hold his bow steady as he aims at his enemy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "his" refers to Joseph who stands for his descendants. AT: "their bow ... their hands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "hands" stands for the person's arms as he is holding his bow steady. AT: "his arms will remain strong as he aims his bow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the hands of the Mighty One
tn.text: The "hands" are expressing the power of Yahweh. AT: "the power of the Mighty One" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: because of the name of the Shepherd
tn.text: Here "name" refers to the entire person. AT: "because of the Shepherd" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Jacob speak of Yahweh as if he were a "Shepherd." This emphasizes that Yahweh guides and protects his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Jacob speaks of Yahweh as if he were a "Rock" that people can climb upon to find safety from enemies. This emphasizes that Yahweh protects his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Jacob continues to bless Joseph and his descendants. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:gen:49:22|49:22-23]])
Here "you" refers to Joseph who stands for his descendants. AT: "help your descendants ... bless them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "sky" stands for the rain that helps the crops to grow. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: blessings of the deep that lies beneath
tn.text: Here "deep" stands for the water underneath the ground that supplies rivers and wells. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: blessings of the breasts and womb
tn.text: Here "breasts and womb" stand for the ability for a mother to have children and feed them milk. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Jacob continues to bless Joseph and his descendants.
The meaning of the original language is not certain. Some Bible translations have "my ancestors" instead of "ancient mountains."

tn.ref: May they be on the head of Joseph
tn.text: Here "they" refers to the blessings of his father.

tn.ref: upon the crown of the head of the prince of his brothers
tn.text: Jacob desires for these blessings to be passed on to even the most important of his descendants. AT: "on the head of the most important of Joseph's descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"most important of his brothers"

Here "Benjamin" is a metonymy that stands for his descendants. Jacob speaks about Benjamin's descendants as if they were a hungry wolf. This emphasizes that they will be fierce warriors. AT: "The descendants of Benjamin will be like hungry wolves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: These are the twelve tribes of Israel
tn.text: "These" refers to the sons Jacob mentioned in 49:1-27. Each son became the leader of his own tribe.
Here the word "blessed" refers to the speaking of formal blessings.

tn.ref: Each one he blessed with an appropriate blessing
tn.text: "He gave each son a fitting blessing"
"he commanded them"

tn.ref: I am about to go to my people
tn.text: This is a polite way of saying he is about to die. AT: "I am about to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]]))

Jacob is referring to where his inner man will go when he dies. He expects to join Abraham and Isaac in the afterlife. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]]))
This is the name of a man. "Hittite" means "descendent of Heth." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:23:07|23:8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Machpelah was the name of an area or region. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:23:07|23:9]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

This was another name for the city of Hebron. It may have been named after Mamre, the friend of Abraham who lived there. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:13:16|13:18]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Jacob continues speaking to his sons.
The purchase can be made explicit. AT: "in it were purchased by Abraham" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"from the Hittites"

tn.ref: finished these instructions to his sons
tn.text: "finished instructing his sons" or "finished commanding his sons"

tn.ref: he pulled his feet into the bed
tn.text: Jacob was sitting on the bed. Now, Jacob turns and puts his feet in the bed so he can lie down.
This is a polite way of saying a person died. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
After Jacob died, his inner man went to the same place as his relatives who died before him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]]))

tn.ref: that he collapsed on the face of his father
tn.text: The term "he collapsed" is an idiom for being overcome. AT: "that he fell on his father in grief" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"his servants who took care of dead bodies"
To "embalm" is a special way of preserving a dead body before it is buried. AT: "to prepare his father's body for burial" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
"They took 40 days" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"70 days" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"days of mourning him" or "days of weeping for him"

tn.ref: Joseph spoke to Pharaoh's royal court
tn.text: Here "royal court" stands for the officials that make up Pharaoh's royal court. AT: "Joseph spoke to Pharaoh's officials" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: If now I have found favor in your eyes
tn.text: The phrase "in your eyes" is a metonym that stands for Jacob's thoughts or opinion.  AT: "If I have found favor with you" or "If you are pleased with me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is an idiom that means that someone is approved of by someone else. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: please speak to Pharaoh, saying, 'My father made me swear, saying, "See, I am about to die. Bury me in my tomb that I dug for myself in the land of Canaan. There you will bury me." Now let me go up and bury my father, and then I will return.'
tn.text: This has a two level quotation and three level quotation. These can be stated as indirect quotations. AT: "please tell Pharaoh that my father made me swear that after he dies I would bury him in the tomb that he dug for himself in the land of Canaan. Please ask Pharaoh to let me go bury my father, and then I will return" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: See, I am about to die
tn.text: "See, I am dying"
It was common to use the phrase "go up" when speaking of traveling from Egypt to Canaan.
It is implied that the members of the court spoke to Pharaoh, and now Pharaoh is replying to Joseph. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"as you swore to him"
It was common to use the phrase "went up" when speaking of traveling from Egypt to Canaan.

tn.ref: All the officials ... the courtiers ... the senior officials
tn.text: All of Pharaoh's most important leaders attended the burial procession.
This person was a royal advisor.
Here "household" refers to Pharaoh's royal court.

tn.ref: land of Egypt, with all Joseph's household and his brothers, and his father's household
tn.text: This can be translated as a new sentence: "land of Egypt. Joseph's household, his brothers, and his father's household also went with him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_events]])
Here "household" refers to their families.
Here this stands for the men riding in the chariots. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: It was a very large group of people
tn.text: "It was a very large gathering"
The word "they" refers to the participants in the burial procession.

Possible meanings are 1) the word "Atad" means "thorn" and it may refer to a place where large amounts of thorns grew, or 2) it may be the name of the person who owns the threshing floor. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: they mourned with very great and grievous sorrow
tn.text: "they were extremely sad and they mourned very much"
"a 7 day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"in the threshing floor of Atad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: This is a very sad occasion for the Egyptians
tn.text: "The mourning of the Egyptians is very great"
The translator can add a footnote that says: "The name Abel Mizraim means "the mourning of Egypt.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"So Jacob's sons"

tn.ref: just as he had instructed them
tn.text: "just as he had directed them"
"His sons took his body"
Machpela was the name of an area or region. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:23:07|23:9]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

This was another name for the city of Hebron. It may have been named after Mamre, the friend of Abraham who lived there. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:13:16|13:18]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a man. "Hittite" means "descendent of Heth." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:23:07|23:8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"Joseph returned to Egypt"
"all who had come with him"

tn.ref: What if Joseph holds on to anger against us
tn.text: Here anger is spoken of as if it was something physical that Joseph could hold in his hands. AT: "What if Joseph is actually still angry with us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: wants to repay us in full for all the evil we did to him
tn.text: Avenging oneself against someone who harmed him is spoken of as if the person were paying they other person what they are owed. AT: "wants revenge for the evil thing we did to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Your father gave instructions before he died, saying, 'Tell Joseph this, "Please forgive the transgression of your brothers and their sin when they did evil to you."'
tn.text: This has a two level quotation and a three level quotation. They can be stated as indirect quotations. AT: "Your father instructed us before he died to tell you to forgive us for the evil thing we did to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: Your father gave instructions before he died, saying
tn.text: Jacob was the father of all the brothers. Here they say "your father" to emphasize that Joseph needs to pay attention to what his father said. AT: "Before our father died he said"

tn.ref: and their sin when they did evil to you
tn.text: "for the wicked things they did to you"
This does not mean "at this moment," but is used to draw attention to the important point that follows.

tn.ref: please forgive the servants of the God of your father
tn.text: The brothers are referring to themselves as "the servants of the God of your father." This can be stated in first person. AT: "please forgive us, the servants of the God of our father" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: Joseph wept when they spoke to him
tn.text: "Joseph wept when he heard this message"
They lay down with their faces toward the ground. This is a sign of humility and respect for Joseph. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: Am I in the place of God?
tn.text: Joseph uses a question to comfort his brothers. AT: "I am not in the place of God" or "I am not God." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"you intended to do evil against me"
"God intended it for good"

tn.ref: So now do not be afraid
tn.text: "So do not fear me"

tn.ref: I will provide for you and your little children
tn.text: "I will always make sure you and your children have enough to eat"

tn.ref: He comforted them in this way and spoke kindly to them
tn.text: "He comforted them by speaking kindly to them"
"110 years" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: Ephraim's children to the third generation
tn.text: "Ephraim's children and grandchildren" (UDB)
This is the name of Joseph's grandson. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: who were placed on the knees of Joseph
tn.text: This expression means that Joseph adopted these children of Machir as his own children. This means they would have special inheritance rights from Joseph. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
In [[:en:bible:notes:gen:50:24|50:24/26]] the word "you" refers to Joseph's brothers, but it also stands for their descendants. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: lead you up out of this land to the land
tn.text: It was common to use the word "up" when speaking of traveling from Egypt to Canaan. AT: "bring you out of this land and take you to the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_events]])
To "embalm" is a special way of preserving a dead body before it is buried. See how you translated "embalmed" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:50:01|50:1]].
This can be stated in active form. AT: "they placed him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"in a chest" or "in a case." This is a box a dead person is placed in.
